content:
I count myself fortunate to have spent time with Brooklyn-born Arnold Packer. Arnold was the Assistant Secretary for Policy, Evaluation, and Research in the U.S. Department of Labor during the Carter administration. His insights and innovative thinking around economics, employment and training policies helped many people, particularly young people to reach their full potential.  Arnold passed away aged 85 in mid-October. The last project we were working up with my colleage  Ervin Dimeny  was around verified resumes. Thanks to the  Urban Institute  report by  Robert Lerman   Daniel Kuehn  and  Pamela Loprest   - wonderful insights into the topic.  Love to hear your thoughts on  #verifiedresumes  - join the conversation. Stay safe.  #research   #training

content:
Great to talk with Fox Business today on why companies should invest in Apprenticeship ?  I know many people reading this have already invested and they see the returns first hand every day.  Love to hear your experience.  For those considering taking on an apprentice or starting a program - here is some compelling reasons to give it a go... Firstly, an apprenticeship  program is one of the best investments a firm can make - U.S. Department of Labor statistics show that companies with apprenticeship programs earnt a return on investment of $1.46 for each dollar invested.  That is an average - in some sectors the ROI has been estimated at as much as $11 for every dollar invested !   Apprenticeship programs also provide employers with opportunities to improve workplace productivity, improve workforce diversity and build a pipeline of workers with the precise skills needed in your workplace (now and into the future). They can help shape the employee to your workplace culture and can strengthen your brand as an employer of choice; and finally boost employee retention.   #apprenticeship Watch:

content:
Students in Darwin in Australia’s Top End will gain valuable real-world skills in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), thanks to the Pathways in Technology (P-TECH) Australia program. Exciting that Casuarina Senior College in Darwin is the first P-TECH in the Northern Territory. P-TECH is an innovative model of collaboration between education and industry and will provide an industry supported pathway for young people in the NT and build the skills they need for the jobs of the 21st century. Maritime and defence industries are growing quickly in the NT so the Australian Industry and Defence Network will be a key partner on this P-TECH. I was pleased to join the conversation at the inagural planning meeting with energized employers and educators at Casuarina Senior College last week. The first P-TECH school was established in the US by  IBM  in 2011 in collaboration with the New York City Department of Education, The City University of New York, and the New York City College of Technology. IBM is the industry partner for the Ballarat Federation College Partnership. #STEM Jade Moffat Herman   Amy-Lou Cowdroy-Ling   Janine McPhee   Nathan Ellery   Rashid Ferrod Davis   Sharna Peters   Louise Davis

content:
Despite the upbeat news on the vaccines, I think we are struggling mightily across the nation with three key issues: (1) Pandemic fatigue including Zoom fatigue; (2) Absence of interpersonal touch and connectivity; and (3) Upcoming holidays and "tradition" changes that distance us.  In a sense, the second "surge" feels, at least to some of us, worse than the first surge; the numbers are perilously high; we have a dysfunctional transition of power (whatever your political persuasion) that is harming our nation. Some of us have become more isolated than perhaps even necessary due to fear as others flaunt mandates and best practices.   In a sense, we are unaccustomed and unprepared for what is happening in our nation.  We can rightly ask: how do we move forward with grace and wisdom and perspective?  What compensatory mechanisms can we deploy to help all those who need help? And, what about our children and their ability to navigate forward?   I have one thought: I have hope.  I still believe despite some evidence to the contrary that people are decent and caring and at the end of the day, the better side of humanity and the wiser voices will rise to the top and be seen and heard.  I still have hope.   Do you? 
 
 
 …see more

content:
The absence of a concession by Trump is but one of the difficult issues our students need to process and understand.  I just published a free download for educators on how to discuss the election in a non-partisan way. Once the concession issues are unfolded and addressed, I will add more to the list of teaching tools. I have also recognized that in a world of online learning, some of my books need to be made available as PDFs. That now includes the Tongue Twister book and the Lady Lucy Laugh Giraffe book, both of which are trauma responsive. They can be found at  https://lnkd.in/eaWQeJ6 .  In terms of resources, there is also a Trauma Toolbox How To Guide and The Feeling Alphabet Activity Set, also available at a reasonable price on my website. Finally, I am working on a Holiday Kit -- a type of trauma responsive bag that will help children and families navigate the inevitable changes of the coming holiday season (no Santa's lap; no in person caroling in close proximity.  Please access these resources.  Our children need them -- the amount of trauma is real and not declining.

content:
Consider enrolling in this course on Trauma Anniversaries at Rutgers Graduate School of Social Work, Dec. 9 online from 9 --12. See link to learn about course and registration. $60.  https://lnkd.in/dpyNStH .     In addition to social workers, this will be a valuable course for school psychologists, educators, HR personnel, among others. The point is that many anniversaries are coming up and the prior traditions for dealing with anniversaries have changed. How do we handle the pandemic anniversary and the anniversaries of those who passed away from COVID? How do we deal with anniversaries of traumatic events like suicides and shootings and death by overdoses?  We need to plan and reflect ahead of time so we don't end up retriggering older trauma.  Hope to see you there. The time to do the planning is now.

content:
Well, another quandary with respect to which I need some insight.  I just read the stories about the predator/ cult leader Larry Ray and his involvement with students at Sarah Lawrence College (including his own daughter).  It took a while but he was just arrested (later than necessary). The NYMagazine piece is chilling. My questions do not relate to the power of a cult figure on young people.  We have many examples of this... sadly. Here’s what I don’t get:  where were the Sarah Lawrence administrators and staff? Apparently, at least one knew something was “up” in a specific dorm and did not address the issues.  Perhaps a parent can spend a night or two or three in a dorm but Larry Ray’s stay appears to be much longer.  Didn’t folks notice?  Wasn’t there an RA?  I frankly am hard pressed to believe the College could claim to be so hands off or ignorant or accepting of parents living on campus. Weren’t red lights flashing? Lives and relationships were ruined.  What responsibility did/does Sarah Lawrence have and are the personnel then there  still employed?  Years in question seem to be 2010 — 2014.   There must be another piece or two of three that I am missing.  I have known some administrators there — remarkable people. Explain to me what happened please.

content:
I have been doing a lot of thinking lately about how the government spends money -- how it allocates its dollars (our dollars).  I have been struck by the no-bid Cerner contract with the VA to move to electronic health records which is estimated to cost $16 billion.  No typo.  See:  https://lnkd.in/e-bR3RW .   So, here's my question: What can you get for $16 billion if we had other spending priorities?  What disease could we cure for that amount?  Could we have universal early childhood education for that amount?  We have legislation with mandates that are unfunded; suppose we looked at some of those to fund?  A recent NY Times piece noted the proliferation of child pornography on the web and the absence of sufficient resources allocated to stomping out this problem. The legislation exists; the dollars don't. Bottom line: How can a private company get a $16 billion no bid contract when we have so many other needs?   Ask yourself: What can $16 billion buy? 
 
 
 …see more

content:
I just read an article in InsideHigherEd about the 15 new incoming students at Hampshire College. IHE referenced a Boston Globe article describing the feelings of these students and those who chose to attend elsewhere.   Because Hampshire is struggling, they limited 1st yr enrollment.  And of those accepted, only 15 students deposited.  Reflecting on small entry classes, why is  it necessarily a bad idea to be one of those students and for some, it cld be beneficial. Start w/ this: the students know the institution is struggling. They chose to go to an institution that is free spirited and now working to solve fiscal issues.   Might that be like an adventure for some? A bonding experience?  Being a part of something bigger?  Pursuing new pathway in higher ed?  Isn’t that the Hampshire way?  Anti-complacency?  Yes, it might be a costly student experiment—financially and otherwise. But, this is not pro forma college with consistency; this is like an entrepreneur’s start up.  I raise this because I’m still struggling to save a small college that wld clearly need a soft reboot. I don’t think all students wld avoid that. Some might like the effort, energy, commitment. Just saying: small entry classes aren’t all bad. These 15 students are bold and brave.  Bravo/brava. Rainbows.

content:
Help me understand.   We have shootings in workplaces and that doesn't stop the way we treat violence and guns. We have shootings in an elementary school. Same outcome. We have shootings at a concert venue. Same outcome. We have shootings in churches (most recently in Texas). Same outcome.  We have shootings on campuses.  Same outcome.   Safe places -- work, worship, schools -- are now unsafe. Why aren't we doing anything about guns and gun violence?  Last time I checked, these guns were used to kill innocent people, not animals in the wild and not for self-protection.  Without some change, we will not see change in the violence is protected places. What kind of world is that? Oh, we blame mental illness.  Perhaps there has been mental diminution in those who have been the shooters. But, isn't there a link between access to weapons (their purchase and continued use) and gun violence? Might it be time to reconsider--finally --quality background checks, limits on numbers of purchases and a national database that works. What will it take? Post being shot, even Rep. Scalise was not against guns.

content:
See this new article on Princeton and women in leadership. I think it re-hashes what we know (mentoring matters) and misses culture change and self reflection.  My comment follows link:  https://lnkd.in/dTZf4wG I am struck by the total focus on mentoring for women; this is important to be sure and it is not new. What is striking is that there is almost no mention of institutional culture and the need to change that. How important is it to create an environment in which women can thrive as leaders. Were I to institute a look-see at Princeton, I would look at culture first -- what is it in the culture that enables men to seek and thrive in leadership posts. Hard to look inward and admit that there may be cultural biases and impacts and auras. Hard to face a male dominated past and current culture. Hard to be honest about what is inhibiting success. Mentoring matters for real. But, it is not enough. No indeed.

content:
Here is what is worrying me (among other things): recommendation letters. There is a history of such letters being written for teachers to get new positions despite the fact that these teachers have abused students.  We often are less than honest (if omission counts) when we write letters of recommendation.  We assume receivers of letters can read between the lines and know that we are not truly recommending someone but we are being cautious to avoid charges of defamation, libel and other legal risks.   So, posit this hypothetical: write a recommendation letter for Bill O'Reilly.  What should it say? Would all references to sexual abuse/harassment be absent from such a letter?  Ponder this conundrum; recommendation letters are commonplace.

content:
‘Talent Marketing’ I didn’t make that up. It ain’t ‘Marketing’. It’s not exactly ‘employer branding’. When talents get 7-10 job offers every single week.  When companies struggle with paying candidates what FB, Amazon, Microsoft and Google can easily afford. In this reality, you need more than just actively reaching out to candidates. In marketing, Lead-gen will get you that steady flow of leads every business needs. But Demand Gen will always get a much higher conversion rate. Talent marketing follows the same rule. You want these talents to be interested in you. You want them to approach you. You want them to WANT.  #hr   #hiring   #career   #marketing

content:
The new key factors candidates will look for in their next job post-corona. Pre-corona candidates decided to sign with companies based on 4 key factors: daily commute, the people, the role, and of course, money. Companies actually developed techniques and selling points in order to sell the positions based on these factors, and now we have a game-changer!  After some research on my side, I can tell that things are gonna change. Here are the new 4 key factors that will be considered in the post-corona era: **Financial stability of the company (the company fired staff during corona, or sent employees to unpaid leave) **Work-life balance (did the company take into consideration work hours for employees with kids, WFH)  **Social responsibility (companies that helped during the corona with donations, volunteering, and technology)  **A place to stay for the long term (according to salary, perks, and people). WDYT? What will be the new key-factors? (In the picture AppsFlyer Cares van came to cheer up our medical heroes). AppsFlyer  #covid19

content:
Being in a new role as the Head of Product in a company that has so many exiting opportunities going on for it and that the roles of the product, design, and development are so key for its success, could be a lot to take on.  I'm having a great time getting a lot of super interesting work done at my new role at  Halo Neuroscience  such as defining Halo's products and experiences, establishing light processes to help our teams to be more effective, building teams, and getting  Halo Neuroscience  to the next stages. When I reflect back on how I gained my skills and learned some of the best practices I'm utilizing in my new role, I felt I owe a huge "THANK YOU" to a few of the product and design leaders I've worked with in the past and learned tremendously from. Thank you  Tim Roberts ,  Marianne Braunstein ,  Sumner Paine ,  Nick Myers ,  Jonathan O. , and  Ayse Kulahci . I'm putting a lot of the things I've learned from you into practice every day. I appreciate your leadership and mentorship throughout my career.  #mentorship   #leadership   #product   #productdevelopment   #productmanagement   #bestpractices   #buildingproducts   #teambuilding

content:
I’m actually jealous  It doesn’t happen often, and never when talking about medicine or healthcare, but I’m jealous of those citizens who are already receiving the COVID-19 vaccination. So says the first recipient: “I can finally look forward to spending time with my family and friends in the new year after being on my own for most of the year.” That’s the feeling I want to have—joy, relief, self-respect and duty to my country.  Good behavior with mask wearing and good citizenship are normal parts of my behavior when it comes to COVID-19, and it takes effort—I’ve got my many masks on me all the time, hand sanitizer handy. I’m weighing going (and not going) to stores, movies, not hugging friend, not going into their homes and on it goes. And I’ll keep doing all of these things but it is getting harder to do—I mean who doesn’t want to have a cozy meal with friends? I trust science and medicine—over the last 150 years, modern healthcare has done more to improve our lifespan than any other factors—clean water, clean sanitation, antibiotics, vaccinations, dental health, are the cornerstone to our collective health and why we now live past the age of 50. So when my time comes to get vaccinated, I’ll put on my Sunday Best, roll-up my sleeve and proudly get injected.

content:
Every one wants to enjoy the holidays and who can blame us? It’s been a terrible year for infectious diseases (well, really only one...) and it’s wreaking havoc. Every single day, more than 150,000 of our beloved American friends and family members are getting infected. And every single day 1,200 friends and family members are dying. It’s sobering and it’s scary. But those of us that have the strength of body and mind can help reduce the fear, and help reduce the spread of this Killer (COVID-19) by showing their love and neighborliness by wearing a mask and keeping some distance—even during these times of gatherings.  (After all, a mask is just a mask...just like a broken arm needs a cast, it’s just a cast...) This article gives some great tips about how to stay safe while gathering with our friends and family, and while sharing our love and togetherness, which we all need right now!

content:
Dogs are people’s best friends…Especially Now.
 
 Studies show that they help us lower our blood pressure and deal with stress. But we don’t need studies to tell us what we know already! Dogs also help us get more exercise and spend more time in nature. They always love us and they are always happy to see us. In some ways, dogs show us what ‘goodness’ looks like in all of us too!
 
 Due to the ongoing pandemic, there has been an onslaught of negative news that can cause us to get mired in the spiral of depressing articles. However, it seems that a spike in dog adoptions during COVID-19 is one positive outcome that we can feel good about, as adoptions increased significantly in March and April. 
 
 So if you have a dog, or cat, or are thinking of adopting, make sure you have the  time--and love in your heart—to commit to them…Like they will commit to you.
 
 FTI Consulting’s Lindi Jarvis, CA, CFA, CPA CFF, and Vincent Flores, CFE contributed to this story.

content:
In Other News: A Win For Patients Personal Digital Charts as I call them, or soon to be known as ‘personal digital medical records’ are coming to your smart phone soon! Federal officials on Monday released groundbreaking rules that will let patients download their electronic health records and other health care data onto their smartphones. “Patients should have control of their records, period. Now that’s becoming a reality,” said Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar. “These rules are the start of a new chapter in how patients experience American health care.” Who are the winners? Patients, people and medical providers who want to understand, manage and control their medical and healthcare needs. Who are the losers? Electronic Medical/Health Record (EMR/EHR) companies who want to own your data to make even more money off your pain and suffering. Finally patients will have all the information at their fingertips  to help them make timely decisions —a good first step for all of us.

content:
It’s Finally Here: Machines As Doctor and  Diagnostician  Researchers found that deep learning algorithms correctly detected disease in 87% of cases, compared to 86% for healthcare professionals. Wow. Many of us who follow ‘deep learning’ and AI markets have seen this in radiological images (X-rays), and now there is evidence that machine-based data accumulation can ‘crunch’ and analyze information to provide better diagnoses than a doctor who has seen hundreds (or thousands) of patients with a similar disease or problem.  Think of what this can do to bring more reliable diagnoses to patients and, think about how such technologies can help patients in under-resourced areas get diagnosed and treated sooner. Talk about Democratizing health care! This is a huge leap forward for Public Health. Now....how do we get Humans to trust Machines?? Selected Excerpt: “"Machines... can have a massive impact on problems in healthcare, big and small, but unless we can convince clinicians and the public of its safety and ability then it won't be much use to anybody..”

content:
We’ve seen it coming but now it’s here: smart apps that are replacing-or displacing-the need for doctor’s visits! And there is probably more displacement than just doctor's visits—now Alexa can tell if your breathing is raspy due to a cold or pneumonia! It can tell if your child is autistic, it can be your post-hospital ‘visiting nurse,’ it can order your medicines when you are running low...it can comfort lonely seniors and let kids with cancer talk to other kids with cancer about their medical journey. Ok—it can’t do all this...yet...but very, very soon. And all these medical capabilities are accomplished via AI and machine learning systems--and whether it is to differentiate cardiac pain from indigestion these home monitoring devices are providing to be highly accurate—more than doctors would be. So, welcome your new Doctor/Nurse Alexa. Selected Excerpt: “These devices correctly identified agonal breathing in 97% of instances, while registering a false positive only 0.2% of the time...Alexa could send vitals to a doctor’s office before you head to your appointment and continue to monitor your condition after you get home.”

In Case You Missed It: Life Saving Medicine Now (Sorta) Affordable Good News: Insulin is now only going to cost people in Colorado $100.00/month, regardless of what the insurance companies or pharmaceutical companies or middlemen want to charge patients.  (According to many sources, the cost of insulin has tripled in the last three years costing patients $6,000.00 per year!) Bad News: This is still really expensive for a lot of people —that’s $1,200.00 per year! Especially since over 100 million Americans have diabetes!  Good News: Even though you have to be a resident of Colorado to benefit from this cap, it’s a strong start and a model for all other states. Let’s hear it for common sense and great legislation.

content:
Who is Responsible For Our Old People? While riding public transit today I ran across this elderly man who was displaying clear signs of dementia and appeared disheveled. He posed no risk to himself or others. Not sure if he was on his way to or from somewhere. Not sure if anyone wondered when he’d arrive or worried if he didn’t show up.  He seemed utterly alone, which seems painful given his senior years and confused state. Maybe we don’t (collectively) care...but somehow it struck a sad cord in my heart as I watched him point to no one and talk to no one. At one point in time, he was someone’s child and might be someone’s father. Where are people like this supposed to live? Who is supposed to help them. Where is our humanity—and even absent that—where is our infrastructure which should exist in a democratic society which holds that all people are created equal and deserves compassion?

In case you missed it: Farmers Can Opt Out Of The ACA... But how are they to pay for their broken legs, diabetes and pregnancies? No problem as long as they have cash. The Farm Bureau  will be allowed to sell skimpy health care coverage while offering false hope of good quality health insurance to its members . Farm Bureau officials estimated that about 42,000 people would eventually take its coverage and promised lower rates than plans complying with federal mandates. They believed the takers would be individuals without coverage or struggling to pay for individual coverage. I hope that ‘life on the farm’ is as healthy as it sounds since the new insurance coverage might not pan out the way it’s been sold to the farming community. Selected Excerpt: “...The Farm Bureau would be able to set higher rates or reject coverage for people who have pre-existing medical conditions. They also suggested that coverage could be limited for large expenses, such as a pregnancy or cancer treatment.”

content:
Coping when you get sick or injured—it’s tough. My husband came home yesterday in a cast after tearing his Achilles’ tendon. And he was very irked and cranky.  Every day people break bones, sprain ankles, get diagnosed with pneumonia, chicken pox, get their hip replaced and many other ailments that require people “staying put” for a week or three. So what’s the best way to move past being mad or irritated or depressed during a period of injury or illness? Step one. Accept the current reality of the situation. Step two? Reframe the situation—For example if you are ‘bummed out’ you can’t play tennis for three months, think  ‘now an opportunity to read those books I’ve been wanting to read’ or to ‘learn to cook those four dishes that I’ve  just haven’t gotten around to...’ Truth is there’s lots that can be done during this ‘down time,’ so think ‘Crisis as Opportunity.’

Here I am again cheerleading for an "Outsider" to come to Healthcare's aide!  I've been a consistent advocate for new entrants with bold ideas driven by creative, optimistic leaders, to provide CPR!  Like Apple and Amazon. My belief is that  "The Healthcare Institutional Mindset"  (including hospitals, nursing facilities and delivering systems) is one which is fundamentally risk-adverse, backwards-thinking and myopic.  Within these organizations you will not find "skunk works" or "innovation labs" or "stealthy teams" working on new approaches to patient care. In healthcare we are designed (and hire) for being slow, cautious and repetitious ... even if doing the same thing over and over leads to the same mediocre and disappointing results. Again I say "Apple, come find me! I'm just up the road and am here to help improve care delivery for patients !" Selected excerpt: "The iPhone, which turned 10 this summer, already aggregates some health data in apps. But most of that is patient-generated. If the company can add information from doctors offices and clinics—test results, visit summaries, medication lists—the iPhone could become an important healthcare tool in achieving interoperability, which has for so long frustrated the industry."

content:
3D bioprinting has recently seen some setbacks, especially due to Organovo's announcement about changing the company's course.  But this is something to provide hope again. A novel type of ink enables bioengineers to print bone-like material at room temperature with living cells. It's a big feat considering the fact that bone is a mixture of living and inorganic compounds in a highly structured mineral matrix. The team is trying to print larger samples and has begun small animal tests to see if a print can repair a large wound. In the US, the FDA has already signaled that 3D-printed bone technologies are eligible for FDA clearance. I’ve explored what 3D bioprinting can do today and what it promises for tomorrow in various parts of my e-books on The Medical Futurist.  Grab ‘The Future of Digital Health’ e-book bundle to get 6 e-books with a special new year deal with 50% off!  https://lnkd.in/eBNrVsM   #3dbioprinting   #3dprinter   #3dprinted   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #technology

I’m really glad Nicole Mpofu reached out to me and raised my attention to how they’re trying to tackle this issue  Codethink . Their team is working on designing a fully open-source research device for experimenting with shining light into skin and detecting the light that reflects, gets absorbed and passes through. The kind of technology that is widely deployed for measuring heart rates. content:
The  FDA ’s new A.I. action plan just got published. Here are the main points: 1. Tailored Regulatory Framework My take: As the draft guidance about this with details will come out this year, I hope adaptive algorithms will be covered. 2. Good Machine Learning Practice My take: The FDA wants to harmonize such practices across a range of international organizations. I'm not sure it’s possible, since their detailed plan is still not ready. 3. Patient-Centered Approach My take: I would’ve expected the digital health arm of the FDA to appoint a patient engagement advisory board, as promoting a patient centric approach without actively involving patients sounds like a risky business. 4. Regulatory Science Methods Related to Algorithm Bias & Robustness My take: This is why we expected that the FDA would take over our open access database of A.I.-based medical devices that we published in Nature Publishing Group's npj Digital Medicine paper. However, they confirmed to me that they won’t. 5. Real-World Performance  My take: The FDA should promote the importance of prospective studies when it comes to analyzing algorithms' performance in medical tasks.

content:
Recently, I shared a report that stated: "It takes roughly seven patients presenting after an abnormal pulse alert to establish one clinically actionable cardiovascular diagnosis." I described that you cannot expect one digital health technology to solve a medical issue in itself. And you cannot avoid using such technologies in healthcare to provide sufficient care. This is why digital health is a cultural transformation where you can't just drop a technology into the system and expect everything to get better. You need both patients and medical professionals to be on the same page, discuss the expectations and side effects and work together by using that technology. This is the topic that we address in the newest article on  The Medical Futurist .  #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology

content:
While I write often about the limitations of artificial intelligence and what it can really offer in practice today, sometimes I come across developments in A.I. that not only blow my mind away but also depict an exciting vision of the future of healthcare. Look at this: In some cases, patients need injections with an iodine-based dye (radiocontrast) to make their organs more visible in scans. But some patients can’t take the dye. So researchers developed a GAN (generative adversarial network) that generates labeled, undyed CT images of lesions on kidneys, spleens, and livers. They added these images to real-world training data to improve performance of a segmentation model that marks lesions in diagnostic scans. As it's really hard to get enough quality medical data to train the algorithm on and labeled medical data is even harder to find, GANs are making it easier and less expensive to create large, annotated datasets for training A.I. diagnostic tools.   #artificialintelligence   #ai   #aihealthcare   #digitalhealth   #futureofhealthcare   #themedicalfuturist

content:
I can't tell you how proud and excited I'm now to share the newest e-book from  The Medical Futurist  with you. This time, we decided to try to tackle the beast: the issue of privacy in the digital health era. While the e-book focuses on practical recommendations and examples about YOUR privacy, it presents details on three levels: 1. Healthcare institutions holding on to your data (your medical records) 2. Medical data stored in the technologies you use (from fitness trackers to genetic tests) 3. Medical data stored where you aren’t aware of (from A.I. to the cloud) These three levels should be at the forefront of every privacy discussion going forward. They encompass the traditional, the new and the future spheres where our data is and will increasingly be stored. I truly hope you will find this e-book useful and I look forward to your feedback so we can keep on expanding it. #ebook   #privacy   #digitalhealth   #medicaldata   #healthcare   #futureofhealthcare   #healthtech   #themedicalfuturist

During the attack, the hospital couldn’t accept emergency patients and the woman was sent to a healthcare facility around 20 miles away. It's going to be extremely hard to catch these bad actors. What healthcare institutions can do is to prepare for such attacks by upgrading their cybersecurity systems. content:
DeepMind  just made a nice gesture and shared its predictions about the protein structures of the coronavirus, which causes the COVID-19 epidemic.  The system uses a machine-learning technique known as "free modelling" to help it predict protein structures when no similar structures of protein are available. They decided not to wait for a peer-reviewed paper but published the results now.  They emphasised that "these structure predictions have not been experimentally verified, but hope they may contribute to the scientific community's interrogation of how the virus functions". A.I. in action. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #covid19   #coronavirus

content:
I published this infographic last week and recevied excellent feedback from you. Many thanks for that!  A bit of a context: it's not surprising that by September in 2019, there are already more medical studies mentioning machine or deep learning than in 2018.  It was also expected that oncology, pathology and radiology stand out when it comes to using A.I. methods in medicine. However, I was surprised to see so many studies in psychiatry, surgery and neurology while you don't see discussions, news and announcements about those developments often. At the same time, it seems that cardiology, ophthalmology and dermatology, the specialties with the most exciting news and developments seem to be underrepresented. The explanation could lie in the method I used to mine the database but it's still interesting. (Right click on the image and choose open in new tab for high resolution.) #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

label: Educational Resources

content:
It was really hard to track down the developers of Leela Chess Zero, the highest rated chess engine today, but I managed to find them in a developer forum. It was interesting to learn that the developers are not professional chess players and they don't even need to be to develop such an algorithm.  Imagine the same in medicine. Developers creating the highest rated medical algorithm without having a profound knowledge of medicine. This is the era artificial intelligence is bringing to us. Here is how they described the algorithm works: "Leela Chess uses a neural network trained without human knowledge. The training procedure uses reinforcement learning to train the next generation of the network based on games played using the previous one against itself (“self-play”) so without any external influence. The initial network is trained using random games so there is no human input in the process. The next network improvement comes from using a (small) search tree to improve the neural network’s evaluation of a position and using this outcome, together with the game result, to train the next network. Any principles used during play are discovered this way, but not in a way that can be easily extracted as such. Obviously, the rules of chess are hard-coded in the engine."

content:
There is an amazing country that uses digital health in the right way! In the keynote I gave about Privacy in the Digital Health Era at the recent GLOBSEC event, I analyzed patients' freedom of choice from the digital health perspective. 1) In China, the freedom of choice patients have about digital health technologies is limited because the government makes them use A.I. and other ways of obtaining data about them. 2) In Rwanda, the freedom of choice is there but limited as otherwise they don't get access to healthcare, only through digital health technologies. 3) In the US, patients have a lot of freedom of choice but without proper incentives, medical professionals are not encouraged to get involved. Which country's example do you think I used as the best in the world? Please cast your vote by leaving a comment. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #speaker   #keynote   #speakerlife

content:
The essence of digital health from a recent paper of The Medical Futurist Institute: "Through the cultural transformation called digital health, the hierarchy of traditional medicine is transforming into an equal-level partnership between patients and caregivers. Besides many disruptive technologies, AI has the biggest potential to support this transition by analyzing the vast amounts of data patients and healthcare institutions record in every moment.  By taking away the repetitive parts of a physician’s job, it might lead to being able to spend more precious time with their patients, improving the human touch. However, AI can only fulfill its mission if it remains a safe, efficient, and proven aid in treating patients and improving healthcare." https://lnkd.in/gRGWDxt #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #TMFI   #research

content:
Yesterday, I gave a keynote about artificial intelligence's role in healthcare to a biopharma company. One of the best questions I received was about liability. Who is to blame if an A.I. algorithm makes a mistake? This is a recurring issue and I like to answer it with a metaphor. If a physician listens to your heart sounds with a stethoscope and there was something wrong with the device and it misled the diagnosis, who is to blame? The manufacturer of the stethoscope? Never. The physician is supposed to be using all the available technologies at their disposal and with their expertise and knowledge therefore only they can be blamed, the final decision is their responsibility.  The same applies to the use of A.I. It is a (regulated, supervised and assessed) tool in the physician's hand and thus only contributes to the decisions, not making them.  What do you think? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning 
 
 
 …see more

content:
What can you do when doctor shortages do not allow a country to provide care for everyone? You send out junior doctors to rural regions without any major experience. This is where artificial or augmented intelligence can jump in.  A Chinese company, RXThinking, is training medical algorithms to become super-diagnostician that can be dispatched to all corners of China. Instead of replacing physicians with algorithms, RXThinking's A.I.-based diagnosis app empowers them because it acts like a navigation app for the diagnostic process, drawing on all available knowledge to recommend the best route but still letting the physicians control the decision-making process. Just one example how and why A.I. is crucial for solving healthcare's global issues. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

content:
The question about A.I. is never technology vs humans. GM Garry Kasparov introduced the concept of advanced chess, also known as cyborg or centaur chess. He wanted to bring together human and computer skills to achieve the following results: - increasing the level of play to heights never before seen in chess; - producing blunder-free games with the qualities and the beauty of both perfect tactical play and highly meaningful strategic plans; - offering the public an overview of the mental processes of strong human chess players and powerful chess computers, and the combination of their forces. The most exciting medical studies that used machine or deep learning did not conclude that algorithms are better than physicians at doing a specific task but those that showed how the combination of computational and human cognition leads to the best results.  My favorite studies in this are the ones with detecting breast cancer on slides and diabetic retinopathy on retinal images. Excellent results underscoring the notion that artificial narrow intelligence will work with medical professionals and vice versa for the best results.  Have you seen other similar studies concluding the same? Photo source:  Kasparov.com #digitalhealth   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #TMFchessjourney

content:
Dr. Zsuzsanna Varga, a primary care physician in Budapest, put the Ask Me About Digital sticker on her door.  She told me: “a young girl came in the other day, who saw the badge earlier that week, so she was brave enough to come in and show me the pictures she took with her phone on her urticaria that only comes in the morning. The patient also told me about how she googled her symptoms but couldn’t find any reasonable explanation. She was happy about the badge because she has mixed experiences of googling and interpreting it to healthcare practitioners. I think it’s a great possibility to get closer to younger generations because she felt safe and understood, so she won’t be hesitating next time she has any problem”.  See more stories:  bit.ly/fromchancetochoice #healthcare   #health   #primarycare   #medicine   #digitalhealth

What I learnt here is not that being an influencer with millions of followers without any "traditional" content or quality is bad. What I learnt that for all of us who discuss health, technology and science online, we need to learn how to get quality attention, not just how to provide quality content.  If you have a favorite online influencer in any topic you like to follow, please share which one and why.

content:
I receive a lot of questions about which ECG device can help patients monitor their heart condition. Here are the three most popular and widely available hand-held ECG devices. Kardia (formerly known as Alivecor) has the most studies backing them. Viatom can measure more vital signs besides ECG. And WIWE has a good algorithm behind them. Any other good ECG devices? #technology   #bigdata   #health   #healthcare   #digitalhealth   #ECG

content:
"In their editorial, Keane and Topol, wrote about the A.I. chasm. ""...That is the gulf between developing a scientifically sound algorithm and its use in any meaningful real-world applications. It is one thing to develop an algorithm that works well on a small dataset from a specific population, it is quite another to develop one that will generalize to other populations and across different imaging modalities.""  What ventures in your opinion have the largest potential to cross the A.I. chasm?  https://lnkd.in/gb5D6mH " #ai   #business   #technology   #data   #health   #healthcare

In the last few days, I've asked many specialists to test the Philips Lumify portable ultrasound with me. Physicians who regularly do eye, abdomen and pediatric ultrasounds have checked it out and were all amazed by its features. We'll post the review with videos soon.  It's amazing that I can just grab the device and record an ultrasound examination without prior training then send it to a specialist who can remotely check it out! #POCUS #fromchancetochoice #digitalhealth #future #health #healthcare #medicine #ultrasound

Virgin Management has signed Business in the Community’s Race at Work Charter and committed to 5 important and long-term actions. content:
The surge in emerging market bond issuance illustrates how Federal Reserve policies have opened wide the debt markets to those not having direct support. Per the data complied by Gramercy (thank you), the $327 billion in issuance YTD compares to $278 bn last year and $292 bn in 2018. The good news is that this massive bond issuance has allowed developing countries to avoid liquidity problems/other short-term problems turn into solvency/longer-term problems. Less good is the encouragement to cuspy (in terms of liquidity/solvency) borrowers to over-rely on debt financing. #markets   #debt   #em   #emergingmarkets   #fed   #centralbanks   #federalreserve   #gramercy  @gramercy

content:
This record pace of borrowing reflects an unusual strong alignment of both supply and demand issues ... that feed onto themselves in the SHORT-TERM but could well become quite problematic over the longer-term. These include, for illustration: Direct and indirect market subsidization by central banks; Investors stretching for returns, comforted by their strong comfort in central bank backstops; and Companies that, facing unprecedented revenue hits, are eager to avoid what they view predominantly as short-term  liquidity problems becoming longer-term solvency ones. #markets   #debt   #economy   #investing   #investing   #centralbanks   #bonds   #investors   #interestrates   #liquidity   #fed   #credit   #bloomberg

content:
In 1980 I visited President Jimmy Carter in the White House. I was obsessed with politics. With the people who worked so hard to be “governor” or “Senator” or “president”. I think it was because I was insecure. I didn’t want to be just me. I wanted people to like me, to maybe even VOTE for me. At age 12. When my friends were starting to hold hands with girls and feel that first unusual stirrings of romance, I would go home every day and call Senators and Governors and Presidential candidates for hours. I would write letters to them, maybe 50 letters a day, and steal the stamps from my parents. . . . . #lifestyle #politics #democrate #entrepreneur #writing

content:
GOOD OR BAD: MONOGAMY  Having strong opinions are like a disease. You get one, then your friends get the same one (else, according to the rules of groupthink they are no longer friends) and so on.  I hate opinions. There always seems to be someone smarter than me who has the opposite opinion.  But I'm skeptical. And I like to know things. And think. And learn. And study. AND be entertained. And laugh.  I'm launching a new podcast soon with my friend and bestselling author, AJ Jacobs called "GOOD or BAD". We take topics: Dogs, Monogamy, Cars, Government, Billionaires, Tipping, Democracy, Cosmetic surgery, etc and argue:  "Is this good or bad?"  Sometimes we have a conclusion. Sometimes not.  Here is a teaser for one of the episodes: GOOD or BAD: Monogamy.  If you have suggestions for "good or bad" topics, please let me know in the comments.  Or, if you have opinions on monogamy, leave them in comments and I hope we read out some comments in the episode.  Enjoy! #podcast   #monogamy   #dating   #polyamory   #podcast   #opinions

content:
Firings forced me to look at my life situation, take a bigger picture than I was taking, and figure out the new slices of life I can now taste. Being rejected is an invitation to sample more from life. And having a checklist helped me ignore all the bad chemicals that were trying to bring me down. #Madoff forced me to look at my life with a bigger lens. I started new businesses. I channeled my frustration into more networking, into ideas, into experimenting with my creativity to try new careers. I do the items on this checklist almost every day. Thank you Bernie Madoff. You did very bad things. And I met you when I was lost in my life. This is not about you. Or about me. It's what you and I did together. Here they are... 10 things you need to do if you were #fired yesterday:  http://ow.ly/YhRN30iRjU6

content:
The latest technological advances are slowly starting to reshape a number of industries. Virtual reality applications have already been tested in sectors such as healthcare and automotive. While there is no doubt that a wide range of niches will influence the future, virtual reality and augmented reality technologies are making the biggest breakthrough in online gaming. Game suppliers from all over the globe have recognised the needs of players as well as the massive potential for further growth of the socially distanced form of entertainment. As a result, they have invested heavily in virtual reality and augmented reality elements, improved gameplay and cutting-edge graphics to bring the entire experience to a new level for consumers. I’m publishing this series on LinkedIn called  #Colors  to explore a topic that I care deeply about: the Renaissance Mind. I am just as passionate about entrepreneurship, technology, and business, as I am about art and culture. In this series, I will typically publish a piece of art – one of my paintings – and I request you to spend a minute or two deeply meditating on it. I urge you to watch your feelings, thoughts, reactions to the piece, and write what comes to you, what thoughts it triggers, in the dialog area. Let us see what stimulation this interaction yields. content:
What is keeping you sane? What's keeping me sane, while I wait for a deus ex machina to flip the switch that will return everything to normal, is my trusty rusty exercise bike, purchased years ago for $200 from a neighbourhood gym that was upgrading its equipment.  After ten days of riding in place, I'm chafed and sore, like I've been ravaged by an army of plundering Pelotons, but the sweat that puddles on the floor of my laundry room is my elixir. I'm in charge of manufacturing my own opiates now. I can no longer outsource my joy.  #healthandwellness

content:
Drawing on scientific research and personal experience, authors and friends Lynne Everatt, Deb Mangolt, and Julie Smethurst created Acts of Friendship: a comprehensive, fun and hilarious how-to on overcoming disconnection in our increasingly isolating world. Divided into 47 activities to strengthen friendships old and new, Acts of Friendship is designed to give friends the time and space to reconnect with each other—as well as with their environment, their emotions and their values. Make a “chuck-it” list of things you’ll never do; go on and hike in order to let go of old grudges; communicate your gratitude through haiku. Embark on collective action to reduce your carbon footprint; luxuriate in chocolate facials to rebuke conventional beauty standards; discover your inner child by puzzling over an “ages eight and up” toykit; or host a “Dinner of Truth” and lovingly confront your most annoying traits. In an era of individualism and isolation, Acts of Friendship is a powerful guide to unity and empathy, reminding us that only through deepening our bonds with both the people and the world around us can we arrive at lasting fulfillment  #actsoffriendship   #workplacewellbeing  .

content:
Steve Jobs is best known for conducting one of the most stunning business turnarounds in history: leading Apple from the brink of bankruptcy to become the most valuable company in the world.  But many who worked with the famous founder had a love/hate relationship with their boss. Yes, he was inspiring and innovative. But he could also be overbearing, impatient, arrogant. In fact, it was those latter traits that led to Jobs infamously leaving Apple back in 1985, as Jobs and Apple's board simply couldn't see eye to eye. In the eyes of many, Jobs was a "brilliant jerk." So why is it, you may ask, that in a world that seems to increasingly value collaboration and soft skills like emotional intelligence, do brilliant jerks continue to succeed? The answer's not as simple as you think. (Read more in today's column.) #apple   #emotionalintelligence   #SteveJobs   #management   #leadership   #brilliantjerks   #eqapplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou 
 
 
 …see more

content:
As part of its strategy to adapt to post-pandemic times, Walmart is making some major changes to the way it runs its Supercenters: The company is introducing a new team-based operating model--and giving pay raises to tens of thousands of employees. The new model, which has already been tested at Sam’s Club and Walmart Neighborhood Market stores, includes the following: -Cross-training small teams of associates, who can then better support during busy shifts or support associates who take time off  -New leadership roles, both at the salaried and hourly level -A new pay structure and higher pay for team leads and about 165,000 hourly employees Of course, there’s no way to know in advance how well Walmart will execute on its new plans. But the basic blueprint sends a great message to employees, one that's founded on sound business strategy and emotional intelligence: People over tasks.  Breadth over depth.  Don’t just tell, show. (Read more in today's column.) #walmart   #emotionalintelligence   #criticalthinking   #leadership   #management   #eqapplied #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou 
 
 
 …see more

content:
On Saturday, Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos posted a letter to Amazon employees on Instagram, detailing part of his company's strategy for the coming months in response to the novel coronavirus. One line that stuck out to me more than all the rest: "My own time and thinking is now wholly focused on COVID-19 and on how Amazon can best play its role." Take a moment to let that sink in: Time and again, Bezos has emphasized that Amazon's strategy is a long-term one, more concerned with continuing to evolve and diversify than with short-term goals and profit, something that investors have not always understood or appreciated.  But now, Bezos has made clear that he's entirely focused on adapting his business to a disease that no one even knew about a few months ago. So, what are the lessons for you & your business? The time for wishful thinking is over. The sooner you figure out a way to adapt to the effects of the coronavirus, the better the chance your business has to survive. (Read more in today's column.) #leadership   #management   #Amazon   #Microsoft   #coronavirus   #COVID19   #innovation   #EmotionalIntelligence #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

content:
On the surface, the Cybertruck launch was a disaster. Even many Tesla fans admitted they thought the new E-Truck was ugly. And after Musk boasted that the truck's windows were practically unbreakable, Tesla lead designer Franz von Holzhausen, um...broke them.  But fast forward a bit. Within a week, Cybertruck had won over many of its fiercest detractors. Over 250,000 people were so enamored they were willing to deposit a hundred dollars to be among its first potential owners. So, how do Musk and co. do it? How do they manage to build products that customers are dying to get their hands on? Musk revealed the answer to that question in a recent interview: "A lot of times I think people try to make products that they think others would love but they don't love them themselves. If you don't love the product, you should not expect that others will." (Read more in today's column.) #Tesla   #ElonMusk   #Cybertruck   #innovate   #disrupt   #leadership   #management   #BusinessAdvice   #EmotionalIntelligence   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

content:
POP QUIZ: What do you think is the best motivator for employees? a. cash b. free pizza c. praise and commendation Dan Ariely, Duke professor of psych. and behavioral economics, shared an experiment in which employees working at a semi-conductor factory were promised 1 of 3 things if they could assemble a certain number of chips per day: • A cash bonus of about $30 • A voucher for a free pizza • A complimentary text message of “Well done!” from the boss Interestingly, pizza was the top motivator on day 1—increasing productivity by 6.7 percent over the control group. This is surprising considering the cash only motivated a 4.9 percent increase...and actually resulted in a 6.5 percent drop in productivity for the week. But even more interesting was what turned out to be the biggest motivator:  The compliment. Now, if the promise of a simple text message from the boss can increase productivity, can you imagine what real, sincere, and authentic praise would do? Read more about how to make YOUR praise authentic in my book: "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence." https://amzn.to/2sxFLho #EmotionalIntelligence   #leadership   #management   #PersonalDevelopment   #BestAdvice   #BusinessIntelligence   #careers   #culture   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

content:
How do you even begin to persuade someone who sees the world completely differently than you do? You must provide evidence they're likely to respect. Remember that people differ in background, upbringing, and culture; what one person finds convincing may not work for another. That’s why you must closely examine the arguments of your conversation partner. Ask yourself: •	Who influences and inspires them?  •	What research or sources do they cite?  Next, you can seek data and expert opinions from sources they are likely to heed. (Be careful not to misquote or take information out of context, which will erode your credibility.) These efforts are time-consuming and challenging. But it’s a well-spent investment, because it allows you to present evidence in a way that’s more appealing to your partner instead of wasting time on arguments they’re never likely to consider. Read more about how to achieve emotionally intelligent influence in Ch 6 of my new book, "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence":  https://amzn.to/2sxFLho   #EmotionalIntelligence   #BestAdvice   #leadership   #empathy   #PersonalDevelopment   #management   #negotiation   #relationships   #influence   #respect   #EQ   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

content:
Years ago I was in my first role as a manager, and I experienced an exchange I’ll never forget.  I chastised a team member—we’ll call him David—for a major blunder. My point was valid, but I surely could have delivered it better. David’s response was quick and cutting:  “You know, you’re the kind of manager the rest of us hate.” Ouch. Of course, David could have been more tactful. But there was no use dwelling on that; there was value in this perspective.  So, I took a few moments to let my emotions settle, then came back to David. I asked him why he felt the way he did, and learned from his honesty. In the end, it made me a better manager—and it showed David that I wasn’t the jerk that he thought I was. That's the value of honest feedback, even if it hurts to hear: It will help you grow... If you let it. Check out more in chapter 2 of my new book, "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence":  https://amzn.to/2sxFLho   #EmotionalIntelligence   #EQ   #leadership   #management   #BestAdvice   #careers   #BusinessIntelligence   #communication   #relationships   #PersonalDevelopment   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

content:
Without trust, there can be no love, no friendship, no lasting connection between people. But where there is trust, there is motivation to act.  If you trust someone is looking after your best interests, you will do almost anything that person asks of you.  So, how can you build trust? By doing the following: 1. Listen 1st. 2. Show empathy. 3. Be authentic. 4. Set the example. 5. Be helpful. 6. Disagree and commit. 7. Be humble. 8. Be transparent. 9. Commend sincerely and specifically. Of course, some of these are easier said than done. How can you build these qualities into your daily habits? And companies, how can you build this into your organizational culture? Read the answer in my new book, "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence":  https://amzn.to/2sxFLho #EmotionalIntelligence #empathy #leadership #management  #BestAdvice #careers #BusinessIntelligence #communication #EQApplied #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

content:
Work has radically changed. It's time to embrace it. When you equip and empower your employees to adapt and find the tools they need to be effective and efficient it is an investment in your company’s present and future profitability.  Recently I worked with the largest independent Coca-Cola distributor in the United States. Their remote sales team worked hard, nights and weekends and rarely took time off.  However, sales call volume and sales numbers were down. Morale had plummeted. Paperwork, emails, phone calls, and unmet goals were piling up. Management realized that their team members were frantically busy, but not terrifically productive.  We worked with the sales team members, managers, and the sales leadership team and boosted productivity and performance. As a result, the remote sales team's  total sales calls per week went up over 20% from the prior year, which translated into $2 million in additional revenue.  Embrace the new world of work and make an investment in your company’s long-term growth and profitability.

content:
Today we are publishing an interim edition of Sarah Jeong's 'The Internet of Garbage' available for free download on  theverge.com . Sarah recently left The Verge to join The New York Times and was almost immediately subjected to an astonishing vitriolic attack by right wing trolls. I found it genuinely horrifying to read the death threats (and far worse) directed at a colleague I knew to be anything but the racist she was inaccurately being portrayed as. Sarah, of course, dealt with it grace and humor telling me that at least the trolls were using a decent photo of her. The irony of course is that in her book (first published in 2015) is a seminal work outlining just how online harassment works. You should read it.  https://lnkd.in/dnbMHrq 
 
 
 …see more
label: Educational Resources

content:
I recommend watching this video all the way through. Google admitted to The Verge that it is disturbing, "It is designed to be." But there's something undeniably "Brave New World" about it. Leaving aside the creepiness, the premise seems to be built upon the assumption that understanding the past and present is key to predicting the future. History tells us this is at best only partially true. Even if Google one day manages to harness billions of user data points to help coerce the desired behavior from both the individual and the wider population, I suspect chaos theory will kick in at some point: you cannot predict the unpredictable. To quote Dr Ian Malcolm from Jurassic Park, "Life will find a way" #futurism #technologytrends 
 
 
 …see more

content:
So excited to introduce Community Voices to the  Zero to Infinity  Podcast! Featuring the very best of our community: YOU. 👊 What will Community Voices episodes entail? These episodes will be shorter with the intention of educating you about a particular topic in five minutes of less. Topics include mindfulness, marketing, personal finance, growth hacking, leading a team, raising money, and the list goes on. 🌹 Are you an expert at a particular topic and want to be involved? Comment below with your email and one of our community managers will follow up on next steps! (cc:  Laura Lim   Daniyal Malik   Li (Alice) Wang ) ✉️ Looking forward to hearing from y'all! 💙 What will happen to longer-form fireside chat interviews? They'll still be part of our editorial mix to inspire your career and entrepreneurship journey! They'll just be released less frequently, approximately once a month. Future fireside chat guests:  Purin Phanichphant ,  Kiron Chandy   Allen Gannett   Alan Li   Zach Wigal   Tsion Behailu   Roee Adler Thanks to our past guests too! 2020: A new year, a new decade, so what lies ahead? In this episode of the McKinsey on China podcast, Nick Leung, Chairman of McKinsey Greater China, chats with  Gordon Orr  and  Jonathan Woetzel  about what’s driving the economy—and what’s not. The Chinese consumer continues to power economic growth. Any potential increases in exports from the recently concluded trade deal with the US, however, will not.  This podcast also covers China’s emerging role as a leader in smart manufacturing, technology decoupling between China and the US, and how China could become an exporter of climate mitigation solutions. Subscribe to McKinsey in China on Apple Podcasts.    #china   #economy   #tradewar   #chineseconsumer   #economicgrowth   #asia   #technology

content:
Ten years ago, when a McKinsey consultant left the firm, chances were they headed toward a bank, private equity group, or another professional service firm—in London, New York, Berlin, or another big city. But as our firm changed more in the past decade than at any other time in its entire 96-year history, so did our alumni network. We’ve integrated analytics, AI, digital, design, and other capabilities into the new ways we work with our clients. We’ve opened new offices in 41 cities, many of which lie in emerging markets across Africa, Eastern Europe, and Southeast Asia. And we’ve grown; McKinsey today is 30,000 colleagues strong. So today, that same consultant leaving our firm might launch a mobile healthcare service in India. Or develop self-driving cars in California. Or – heading even farther afield, to the stratosphere – lead a startup to clean up space debris.   #mckinsey   #careers   #professionalservices

I’m very pleased to share our new China Luxury Report 2019: How young Chinese consumers are reshaping global luxury My colleagues at McKinsey surveyed more than 1,000 young Chinese luxury consumers on what makes them tick, unlocking insights into their perceptions of luxury as a form of social capital that distinguishes them from peers in the world’s most populous nation. Our report suggests that by 2025, spending on luxury consumption in China will increase to 1.2 trillion RMB, in the process capturing 65% of additional global growth, and accounting for 40 percent of total global spending. For luxury brands selling high-end shoes, bags, fashion, jewelry, and watches, winning in China means nothing less than winning the global luxury race. https://lnkd.in/fXEJpa8 #mckinsey   #china   #luxury   #consumers   #socialcapital

content:
From driverless taxis to automated cargo trucks, autonomous vehicles (AVs) will change the nature of on-road driving and, in the process, revolutionize the automotive and mobility industries. Within this mix of opportunity and uncertainty, we believe AV players (from components vendors to mobility service providers) could earn trillions in revenues in China. In the long term, China will likely emerge as the world’s largest market for autonomous vehicles. In fact, the Chinese automotive market is already adopting “mobility-as-a-service” (MaaS) at a rapid rate. For example, cars sold to provide mobility services today represent about 10 percent of China’s total cars sales, and the country’s mobility-services market has grown at double-digit rates over the past several years. Read more about this topic in our latest report, "How China will help fuel the revolution in autonomous vehicles": https://lnkd.in/fH4cSai #automobiles   #cars   #China   #technology   #mobility

content:
This excellent article by  Chip Cutter  from his interview with New York architect  Vishaan  Chakrabarti casts light on the drab uniformity of today’s modern urban landscapes.  This is of particular relevance to Asia, where I live. So much of the beauty and distinctiveness of local architectural traditions, many dating back hundreds or thousands of years, have been literally bulldozed into oblivion, replaced by Western temples of consumerism.  Like the hutongs and courtyard homes of Beijing, or the grey brick shikumen style archways and homes of Shanghai, or the red brick structures of old Taipei. These are all almost entirely gone, replaced by the dull, utilitarian and frankly downright depressing structures we find ourselves in today.

content:
It was great catching up with McKinsey's global managing director Dominic Barton in Hong Kong today.  I had the pleasure of working with Dominic back in his Shanghai days, when he led our Asia practice. In the nine years that he has led our firm, we've expanded into many innovative areas of client service, from data analytics, digital transformation, and design, to new business-building, implementation, and leadership development. We've also vastly expanded our reach into new locations around the world. Dominic has spearheaded the founding of Generation, an innovative program that places disconnected young adults in jobs, giving them the skills and support they need to achieve enduring personal and professional success. Since its creation in 2014, Generation has launched in 47 cities across 5 countries – India, Kenya, Mexico, Spain, and the United States.  In total, more than 10,000 students have graduated and 84% of them have found jobs. You can find out more about the program here:  https://lnkd.in/fSbZQUE

content:
Someone should coin "the law of 2020".  It means if you post something positive these days, people try hard to find the negative.  If you dare try and laugh, people will scald you. If you share good news, people will point to privilege or bad news to counteract it. Any wonderful data point is met with " yeah but what about XXXX"  If you point out the huge signs of progress in the world, people will point out your ignorance. It's driven by the media, and their accidental ( and unacknowledged addiction to cheap clicks, which play to misery and fears)  Its distorted our sense of the world, it's genuinely blinded the media to any positivity and algorithms neutralize the ability of good or reassuring news to spread.  It's like a giant self righteous woke festival of misery, a competition to be more anxious, more pious.  There is zero evidence life should be lived in a serious manner. We are all going to die. We can fight for change and justice and for better, and maybe without being so god dam miserable and judgmental and serious. It's not some giant competition to self flagellate with self imposed misery, unless I missed the "this is life in 2020" email.

content:
When steam engines were invented, despite directly producing incredible amounts of rotary force, for about the first 20 years they were used primarily to pump water uphill to drive water wheels. This is the mistake made with most digital transformation. We make the least imaginative change, the fastest, least risky and easiest to get through accounting alteration,  by bolting on the new to what we have.  Next time you see a process with new technology ponder this. Are we adding new technology like oil, or rebuilding around the power of the new. It's 99% the former. This is all in my book.

content:
Our sales team called themselves "data slingers."  10 years ago I was hired by  Mark J. Feldman  to grow a data services brand in a then-emerging  #B2B   #martech  space.  There were only ~100 tools on the map as  #demandgen  teams bought our prospect lists to fuel email/call blitzes.  Some did it well, others simply spammed the living daylights out of those CSV files. Today, not much has changed, and yet, everything is different. Over a decade later, even with 10x more tools, the task of acquiring contacts still threatens to derail even the best laid plans - but this time, it's  #ABM  at risk.  Why can't teams find the right contacts for accounts? Why don't more demand gen pros think in an account-based way, like Sales? Are we ever going to shake our MQL-based ethos? Mark is now the head of revenue operations at Localytics, and I've asked him back for a reunion with me live this Friday at 1:00pm ET for a conversation about how things have changed in 10 years, and today, how to solve this new (but old) ABM data problem.  Live here on LinkedIn we'll dig into: - The messy yet critical task of choosing target accounts, and why less is more - How to find, and use, contact records appropriately  - The truth about working with data slingers like us See you there? 
 
 
 …see more

If she leaves, however, she realizes that she won’t be able to access the bank account because she has nothing with her name on it. Therefore, she is stuck. The program also features a micro-lending program for survivors that includes credit-building opportunities as well as access to financial literacy resources." content:
Do you think about what you consume? I am not talking about food. I am talking about all your intellectual and digital consumption habits…the books you read, the shows you watch, the instagram accounts you follow. Here’s why -  Your output is only ever going to be as good as your input. I am downright snobbish about how I spend my time and what I consume. I don't mindlessly scroll through social media feeds. (I don’t even have Facebook downloaded on my phone - shhh). Your mental input will determine the quality of your life. And THAT is how you stay on track with your goals, aspirations, and hopes for life. What’s something you consume daily that you could trade for a better substitute? P.S. - Pre-COVID, I loved exploring new cities after my keynote. Great way to get fresh input. This was taken in London. If you want to process more on this subject, I was interviewed about what I’ve learned as an entrepreneur and I shared my strategies for both personal and professional success. Link in comments for the full interview on "Coffee with Closers".

content:
2008 and 2018. I was 23 on the left and just starting my company, Zen Media. I’d just finished graduate school and writing my thesis on Twitter. No one believed social media would be a field. It was early (...very early) days. I could have never imagined the highs and lows which would follow. The following year, Business Week would name me to their 25 under 25 entrepreneurs list. Inc and Forbes would follow suit in the years to come...In the 10 years to follow, I’d write two best selling books. The Zen of Social Media Marketing (4th edition now) and Momentum. Zen Media would grow to be a globally known marketing firm with an enviable client list. I’d keynote at hundreds of events in front of thousands. I’d learn what it means to lead people and make a ton of mistakes in the process. I’d know great love and great loss. But, I’d find that in the depth of winter lay within me an invincible summer. And, I’d learn the most important lesson of all - be grateful for your highs and graceful in your lows. 💞 #10yearchallenge

With so many out of work, I thought I'd re-share this piece I wrote on using the "laddering" technique to understand what underlying skills you actually have. Self-assessment can be hard. When we look at "what we do" we tend to get stuck in the definitions of the roles and the industry we are in. By "laddering," and getting to those underlying skills, you can start to see that many if not all are truly applicable to other jobs and even other industries. content:
More  Netflix  history. Prior to 2004/2005, the grey "security screen" printed on the inside of the DVD mailer that prevented people from being able to see what movie was being sent, was a tangle of grey squiggly lines.  After chatting with our Ops team, it was revealed that it didn't need to be that, it's just what was done. So, we changed it to genres instead.   Very few, if anyone, ever took the time to look inside at it. But it was an easy, low-cost way for us to express the Netflix brand. #netflix   #brand   #branding   #dvdmailer   #securityscreen

content:
Some folks think  Netflix  launched streaming fully formed. The reality is that when streaming launched, nothing about it could be considered "great." The streaming quality wasn’t there and the library of titles available to watch was sub-par. Which is why it was launched as a free add-on for subscribers. Also, at-launch, you could only watch via a PC. Then, eventually a Mac. But the challenge the company faced was how to tap into the TV. Smart TVs and internet-connected DVD players were not widespread. Enter gaming consoles. Why? Because the goal was to get Netflix on as many internet-connected devices as quickly as possible. And game consoles already had installed user bases in the tens of millions and their consoles were all connected to the internet. So Netflix partnered with  Microsoft  XBOX,  Sony  PS3, and, believe it or not,  Nintendo  Wii. This was a mock-up of the sticker used on XBOX360 LIVE Gold physical packaging from 2008. Note the title count (12,000) and the rarely defined free trial duration. This was before the move to a 1-month free trial. #streaming   #netflix   #microsoft   #nintendo   #sony   #ps3   #xbox   #wii   #streaminghistory   #OTT   #netflixhistory 
 
 
 …see more
label: Events

content:
When  Netflix  launched streaming, it was only available on PCs. Then on Macs. Then game consoles (XBOX 360, PS3, Wii). Then came the opportunity to be available via  Apple TV. However, despite a back and forth between  Reed Hastings  and Steve Jobs, Jobs stuck to guns - no color logos on AppleTV.  It was too big of an opportunity to let get hung up by the desire to always use a full-color logo so I had the task of trying to figure out how to best represent it with those constraints.  These were the ideas I came up with. If I remember correctly, we ended up negotiating with Apple to either the 2nd or 4th one on the right. But in looking at this again, if you take away the box on the 3rd one on the left, it bears an odd resemblance to the logo as it is today. #Apple   #AppleTV   #Netflix   #logo   #design   #SteveJobs   #NetflixHistory   #netflixlogo   #brand

content:
I see a lot of folks saying, "at that price why not just buy a car?" Well, according to NerdWallet (URL below) the cost of owning a car is just north of $700 a month (and that doesn't include if you have to pay for monthly parking). So, this is actually a pretty brilliant idea from  Lyft . Especially if you live in an urban environment. Not to mention how this perfectly fits the strategic shift to self-driving cars.

Your media presence extends beyond what you do in print, video and social media. It's how you present to customers, staff, clients. Think holistically and strategically about the image you want to portray. Once your brand is established, be consistent in every way. It's good to surprise your audience now and again, to entertain a bit, to employ strategic content marketing tactics to engage them, for instance. But above all, people appreciate knowing what to expect - substance, style, all of the above.

content:
So proud of  Melissa Bosworth , one of  The Aspen Institute 's 2020 Healthy Communities Fellows I've been supporting during this insane year. Melissa is an Assistant Professor at  Regis University  in Denver and Executive Director of the  Eastern Plains Healthcare Consortium . She's an expert on  #healthcare  administration and on  #ruralhealth . But Melissa is also a mother and a wife who's caring for her own ailing elderly mother during a pandemic --while holding three jobs. Melissa wrote a beautiful "love letter" to  #caregivers  during the era of  #COVID19 , and it's been published by  The Denver Post . I'm so pleased to see the Healthy Communities fellows amplify their voices during these tense times, even as they navigate their own complex commitments and obligations. Read Melissa's story below. #cancersupport   #caregiving   #selfcare
