content:
Though American women were "officially" granted the right vote through ratification of the 19th Amendment in August 1920, it took a quite a while longer for Black American women to fully enjoy that freedom. Some say we're still battling, thanks to voter suppression and other tactics aimed at silencing people of color. But this year, Black America must pay tribute to people like the late Emma Sanders, who squared off against some of the most vicious racists America ever produced in Mississippi to ensure that her own party did not discriminate against Black people. I know the path in my journey is paved by the sacrifices of men and women like Sanders. I'm determined her efforts won't be in vain this November.

The statistics don't lie:  just as with African American women, the  #maternalmortality  rates for black women in the UK are five times higher than for white women. This video powerfully explains the core issue: the lived experiences for these women, and how they are treated during interactions with doctors, nurses and even some  #midwives  in pregnancy and delivery settings. This is such a complicated issue, and content that helps explain the crisis is urgently needed.  #globalhealth   #maternalhealth   #reproductivehealth   #reproductivejustice

content:
For a  #FlashbackFriday  during  #WorldBreastfeedingWeek2019 , I'm thinking back to the June 2018 graduation ceremony for  #midwives  at the  #EdnaAdanUniversity  in  #Hargeisa ,  #Somaliland . That's when I met some of the most enthusiastic, energetic and inspiring women I will EVER meet. Many had overcome incredible odds to have the privilege of being mentored by  Edna Adan Ismail . One of the young midwives I met, Kaltoun Yasin, sent me a  Facebook  instant message today to let me know that she is participating in  Harvard University 's  summer  #globalhealth  program, and that she led a presentation on  #maternalmortality  and  #morbidity  yesterday. Kaltoun took great pride in telling the audience that Madame Edna has surpassed her original goal of training 1,000 midwives in Somaliland, and that maternal deaths have dropped significantly since the training program began. At a time when I almost dread engaging with  #socialmedia  each day, I was so grateful that Kaltoun reached out to share her fantastic news. I'm determined to counteract the toxin and negativity in this world with good news like this just as often as I can. Midwife International   Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health #midwifery   #reproductivehealth   #reproductivejustice   #midwivessavelives   #Africa   #maternalhealth

content:
I am so happy to see  #SupremeCourt  Justice  #RuthBaderGinsburg  at the top of this list of The Most Influential People in Global Policy for 2019. She's the reason I can spring out of bed at 5:15 am most mornings.  She helps me realize that I don't have the luxury to give up or give in. That no matter what your age or station in life is, as a woman you have a voice, and you have the right to use it. And you MUST use it. Her example teaches me that, God willing, I'll have another 20 or 30 years left to try to make a difference, to contribute something positive to this world if I work hard to stay healthy and strong. I'll be posting about some of the other amazing women on this list over the coming weeks, because these days,  #genderequality  is MY JAM!  Thanks to @Apolitical for compiling this list, drawn from over 9,000 nominations. It recognises and celebrates the hard work being done on  #genderpolicy  by so many around the world.  #genderequity   #womenandgirls   #womensrights   #humanrights   #reproductivehealth   #reproductivejustice

content:
Though I didn't get my visa in time to travel with photojournalist  Nichole Sobecki  to the  #DemocraticRepublicofCongo , her profoundly powerful images from the scene of the world's second most deadly  #Ebola  outbreak have taught me so much about the inherent genius of  National Geographic  Magazine. I'm not shy about saying that I did a fine job of reporting from the front lines. But Nichole's amazing images telegraph more than I could have captured with twice as many words. I truly regret not being able to observe her at work. I end my week absolutely humbled and profoundly grateful for the turn of fate that allowed me to produce  #globalhealth  content for one of the world's most esteemed publications--and for the ability to learn from some of the finest photojournalists in the world. #photojournalism   #photography   #diseaseoutbreaks   #emergencymedicine   #DRCongo   #DRC   #NatGeo   #TheHotZone https://lnkd.in/enGpGab

content:
Until recently, the 406 students from Pelinia, a remote village in the Drochia district of northern  #Moldova , had no  #toilets  inside their school building. Like many buildings across the country, there was no sewerage system installed, which left them having to brave all sorts of weather to simply use the bathroom. The lack of running water also meant the simple outdoor facilities were often unhygienic. In 2017, 40-year old history teacher,  ludmila turcanu  ( https://lnkd.in/dyh5brg ) herself from Pelinia and a graduate from its local school, along with four other female teachers and a student decided to change this situation. Read about their empowered, inspiring efforts to improve the health and futures of their nation's children via  UN Women . #globalhealth   #globaldevelopment   Women in Global Health   #water   #sanitation   #hygiene   #WASH   #HealthForAll   #childhealth   #education   https://lnkd.in/dWWgyvX

content:
The 15 journalists who attended the  #DeliverForGoodKENYA  journalism workshop in  #Nairobi  typify the very best of  #AfricanJournalism . Their commitment to building their expertise is second only to their boundless energy and capacity to endure great challenges for the sake of their communities and their country’s development. The men and women who participated in yesterday’s workshop eagerly demonstrated their grasp of the upcoming   #Gender  Rule vote in  #Kenya . My goal was to help unlock the stories they should be telling about the importance of  #womensleadership  and participation in progressive national development. These young  #journalism  leaders make me confident that there will be solid, contextual reporting about  #genderequality  in the coming days. #Africa   #TwoThirdsNOW   FIDA KENYA   FEMNET - African Women's Development and Communication Network   #GROOTSKenya   #globaldevelopment   #journalismtraining

Rita Ramirez grew up in Southwest  #Detroit , where 40 percent of residents still don’t have access to home  #Internet . She’s also a member of the only all-female  #mariachi  band in  #Michigan . Rita spends all of her free time connecting families to the Internet and she is AMAZING.  She’s reminding me that you may not be able to save the world, but you can find something to contribute right where you are.    #communityservice   #online   #internetaccess   #informationispower

content:
I can’t stop thinking about the women and girls I met last week at the Fistula Hospital in Borama, #Somaliland. Their stories of pain and isolation were absolutely harrowing, but their strength and determination to survive, and someday thrive, still inspire me.  #Fistula is not just an abstract medical term. For tens of millions of women worldwide, the physical damage endured during childbirth can lead to a life sentence of suffering. And now that I’ve seen the face of it, I’ll do all I can to raise awareness. United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA)  #fistulasurgery #maternalhealth 
 
 
 …see more

content:
Spent part of the past weekend near the Ethiopian border, in the town of Borama and in the Baki District, where 1 maternal and child health center serves a population of more than 14,000 people.  To get there, I traveled some of the roughest, rockiest roads I’ve ever encountered, and tried to imagine being nine months pregnant, trying to get to the clinic in time to deliver my baby safely.  #solemnselfie #globalhealth #maternalhealth #childhealth #midwivesmatter #HealthForAll

content:
In Northern #Uganda, a region where women’s access to reproductive health and #familyplanning services was severely limited due to safety concerns and conflict, male mentors are helping to bridge the gap.   A hundred men in Acholi region have been trained by @CARE to advocate for family planning, by spreading awareness and counseling other men on the health and financial benefits of respecting their wives’ rights to help make decisions on when and how many children they have. And believe me--as someone who has traveled extensively throughout Northern Uganda, this is incredibly important news. Via  News Deeply    #reprohealth #womenshealth #FP2020Global http://bit.ly/2rxJMp0

content:
Journalists worldwide working for news organizations in a business, technology or leadership capacity can apply for a fellowship at  Harvard University  in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The  Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard  and the  Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society at Harvard University   will host at least one fellow for an academic year to carry out a research project on #journalism #innovation. Candidates must propose a project relating to journalism’s digital transformation. Examples might include ideas for new revenue streams to fund journalism, the construction of new tools for reporting or research into news consumption patterns. Check out the link below for more details.... (Thanks for sharing,  Patricia Amira !) #Africa #media #digital

content:
mimetic desire unfolding: chinese mobile app giant embeds payments successfully in a huge closed loop system (WeChat, Alipay). US social media giant desires Chinese success & copies by adding “stablecoin” properties (Libra). Chinese tech desires US social media grand vision and imitates (Huawei). every move points to a splintering of the global financial system (via this mimetic desire dynamic). what remains unclear is how the conflict will be resolved. https://lnkd.in/eb5ZD_A   #crypto   #blockchain   #fintech   #innovation   #socialmedia   #facebook   #system   #huawei   #payments   #wechat   #alipay   #libra

content:
I just got back from San Diego, where the American Economic Association held its annual conference. I've been going to the meetings for close to a decade now, and this year's version looked and felt different. Job interviews (the conference doubles as a giant hiring fair) moved out of hotel rooms, where female candidates have long felt uncomfortable. There was an ombudsperson holding office hours to hear about harassment and abuse. There were even lines for the ladies room. In other words: Economics has made progress in the year since its longstanding problems with sexism and racism burst into public view. Many people told me they have seen the beginnings of a culture shift. And there have also been more concrete reforms: new committees, new policies, new enforcement mechanisms. But it is still unclear whether those reforms will translate into deeper, more lasting change. And in terms of hard numbers, economics has a long way to go: Gender and racial gaps in economics are wider -- and have been more stubborn -- than in many other fields. For more, see my story with  Jim Tankersley  and  Jeanna Smialek  in today's  The New York Times . #economics   #diversity   #gender   #race 
 
 
 …see more

Growth is slowing. The yield curve is inverted. The Fed is cutting rates. So a recession must be coming, right? Not necessarily. But one will come eventually, and you don't want to be caught off-guard when it does. So in today's  The New York Times , I provide a guide to recession-watching -- the indicators that have historically done the best job of predicting a downturn, and what they're showing now. Give it a read, and share your favorite indicators in the comments. #recession   #economy   #federalreserve

content:
When it came to exposing their bad loans, Indian banks had been belly dancing but the Reserve Bank of India forced them to do a striptease. Want to read more on this? Read Tamal Bandyopadhyay's `From Lehman to Demonetization'. It describes graphically how some public-sector banks have been driving down the slow lane to death, loaded with bad assets. Many of the loans that had been restructured following the Lehman collapse continued to haunt them but they were in a denial mode till Raghuram Rajan drove the first of  its kind asset quality review, or AQR, for these banks.  The has traced the rise in the bad debts of Indian banks and tried to go to the roots—as to why assets go bad. Is it the inefficiency of the management? Is it the interference of the government? Rogue corporations? Or, is it about business cycles going bust?  To read the book, visit:  http://amzn.to/2AucbeQ

content:
Physical retail was broken long before the pandemic accelerated its decline. So, thinking that consumers will “go back” to what used to define the physical retail experience means believing that consumers will want to do more of what many had already decided they wanted to do less of: shop in the physical store. The only thing holding many consumers back from abandoning physical retail was inertia, something that the pandemic has motivated consumers to overcome. Now that they have there’s no turning back.

In the last 22 days, Americans have shifted, en masse, from living in a digital-often world to one that is largely digital-only — and  PYMNTS ' third study of 2,000+ U.S. consumers during the course of the global pandemic offers compelling new data as proof, including a tripling in the number of consumers who buy groceries online. The COVID-19 crisis has resulted in a quantum jump in the connected economy, and faster growth. The tragedy is that many traditional physical businesses appear to have lost the possibility of a soft landing, or of gradually transitioning themselves to this digital-only world. Here’s the data and the details.

content:
I quit corporate life 7 years ago with some cash in the bank...I thought I would travel around the world for a year or take a two year break.  Instead, I've been learning about media and dabbling in creating content. I cover the serious topic of finance but I don't take myself too seriously. I have fun making the content. (Pic is from latest shoot in Goa!) I cover my costs such that I still have the original cash in the bank as my emergency cash fund. I say I am retired. People argue with me saying I still work...that's not retirement. Ok, call it what you will. Around the same time, someone coined financially independent, retire early (FIRE). Fine by me. What do you think - what is retirement anyway?   Would you rather learn about retirement from someone who has retired (and has finance qualifications and experience) or someone who is struggling? #personalfinance

content:
How do senior professional women dress in India? Does it vary by industry? Is it ok to vary by audience and purpose? I've struggled with these questions as I moved from Australia with my navy and grey pantsuits to Singapore with sober shift dresses to India where I've embraced colour. I have grown older, of course, but also changed industry and audience focus from investment consulting to financial media, and from B2B to B2C. Does it matter?  I asked Naina Lal Kidwai how she handles the inevitable comments about her dressing; she advised to learn about the weavers.  What do you think?  #professionalwomen   #career

I don't know when ageist, misogynistic name bullying became a thing and acceptable, but it would be really awesome it that would stop. Someone's mother, daughter, sister, relative, friend is named Karen. Or Susan. Or Jenny. Or Sally. As someone who has personally been name bullied for years, I can tell you that it's not "cool" or "socially acceptable". It's ignorant, and hurtful. If you're using the Karen meme/reference (or Susan, or any other name), I kindly ask you to stop. If you see others doing that, please take the time to educate them that it's not OK to make people feel ashamed of their name, and kindly ask them to stop.  #kindness   #humanity   #dobetter

content:
TL;DR: Bravo, Microsoft. Well done!! Nine years ago, I remember having a conversation with a (now-departed) Microsoft executive about the future of Windows Phone. My take was that we would be better off monetizing Office for Mac and Android by making it available on the hundreds of millions of devices already being sold. I distinctly remember saying: "We already own the office productivity market for Desktop, this is the easiest way to win in Mobile - right now. We can fight the hardware battle another day." Emphatically, I was told that I was wrong, without any data to back up that assertion, other than, and I quote: "We will kill the iPhone."  Years later, $40+ billion wasted on Nokia, many lessons learned, we now have this: "But Microsoft has assured CNET that it's sticking with Android and has no plans to make a Windows-based phone. The company's Chief Product Officer Panos Panay was so emphatic about that fact, he told Wired so -- twice" What a tremendous cultural change by Microsoft. Where Steve Ballmer and many of his former leaders fanatically pushed a dying idea to the brink of despair, Satya Nadella smartly monetized Office, embraced the world's biggest phone OS, and quietly beat everyone to innovation. This is how you win.

In a very short time period, the coronavirus has created massive shifts in our lives. One of the things that has changed is the way we manage distraction and how we stay productive during this time of extreme uncertainty.  Before the pandemic, I would’ve advised most people to pay less attention to the news and less attention to social media -- but we’ve reached a point where now these constant updates are necessary to help us navigate the world in a safe and responsible way.  I recently spoke to  Dave Boerger  about the best way to stay productive while staying informed as we navigate this crisis. It was a harsh realization, upsetting realization.  This experience is one of the big reasons why I’m an advocate for scheduling important relationships.  The people who matter most to you should never feel like they aren’t a priority.  How do you schedule time for your loved ones?  #Indistractible   #Scheduling   #Relationships   #Family

content:
When attempting to understand the causes of distraction, it’s incredibly easy to assign blame to technology.  A quick Google search will turn up countless headlines:  “Technology is driving us to distraction” “Smartphones make people distracted and unproductive” “Why we're living in a dark age of technological distraction” The truth is that digital distraction is a symptom, not the sickness. When we put all the blame on tech, the root causes stay hidden.  Unless we deal with the root causes of our distraction, we'll continue to find ways to distract ourselves. Tag a colleague and let me know what you think below!  #Indistractable   #Distraction   #Technology

content:
We are in the midst of the holiday season! As we approach the new year, I want to reflect on all that has happened in the past twelve months. I had a chance to travel the world, visiting beautiful countries like The United Kingdom, Australia, Thailand, and others! I released my second book, Indistractable, to an outpouring of support from all over the world. I had the opportunity to serve and impact many people through my work, resulting in recognition as a LinkedIn Top Voice in Tech for 2019 and nominations for other accolades. Above all else, I began to take back control of my attention, my time, and my life, leading to countless memories made with my family, friends, and loved ones. Through it all, I have emerged endlessly grateful for all that I am able to do and enjoy on a daily basis. I will continue to approach my work and my relationships with the same optimism that I have in the past. 2019 has been great! I have a feeling that 2020 will be even better. To you, my digital community, I say thank you for an incredible year. Happy Holidays and Happy New Year! I’ll see you in 2020! 👋 #Indistractable   #HappyHolidays   #Gratitude   #Reflection

I have found that once you can figure out distraction in one area of your life, there is a ripple effect in all areas of your life.   It took me about 5 years to write my recently-released book, Indistractable. During those five years, my life has changed tremendously.   When it comes to my work, I love to write, but I kept putting off this work that I love because I constantly got distracted.   After writing this book and learning about distraction on a deeper level, I am writing more than ever. I have also experienced improvements in my health and in my relationships with my wife and daughter.   Watch below and share your thoughts! 👇👇👇   #Indistractable   #HumanBehavior   #Health   #Writing   #Distraction

content:
Americans spend $19B a year on gym memberships. Unfortunately, 44% of people quit just six months after joining. These numbers are disheartening, but not overly surprising. Humans are hardwired to chase short-term rewards over long-term benefits. I have struggled with working out for as long as I can remember, so I know that dichotomy all too well. As an obese child, my mother dragged me to the gym to no avail. As a lazy teenager, I desperately joined the wrestling team and never won a match. As an adult, I have tried to prioritize fitness many times, but have failed at each attempt. This was until I found Fitbod, a great app that has helped me consistently go to the gym for over two years. Beautifully designed and with over 3M downloads, it is among the highest grossing and highest rated apps on the Apple App Store. Fitbod has been more than useful to me, but I was surprised to learn that my book, Hooked, was useful to their founders. Fitbod is  Allen Chen 's brainchild and he told me that he designed the initial prototype based on the four parts of the Hooked Model. He identified the internal trigger as not knowing what to do at the gym. Check out the link ⇒  http://bit.ly/2WsOuPM #Hooked   #InternalTrigger   #Indistractable   #Fitness   #Fitbod

content:
That one time ... I tried to be a part of the  TransUnion   #TrueIdentity  campaign. It feels scary living in a world that’s so connected! We challenge our  #TransUnion  teams to build products that solve problems that matter!  In this case helping consumers know when someone is trying to conduct a transaction against their name or when their details end up on the dark web.  Knowing wasn’t good enough so we included features in the product that provide insurance cover and other services that help consumers recover and their restore their true identity! #solvingproblemsthatmatter   #trueidentity   #africarising   #identity   #digital   #informationforgood Garnet Jensen   Tim Collins   Steve De Blanche   Jeannine Naudé Viljoen   Dries Zietsman (MBA)   Nikki Peel   Chad Reimers   Kriben Reddy (MBA)

content:
Empathy in founders is a highly underrated skill. And yet the best founders I have interviewed are deeply empathetic, often because they have had to overcome their own adversity. One such founder is the brilliant founder  David Rogier  of  MasterClass  who I had the pleasure of interviewing earlier this year. He said in his interview:  “I stutter. When I was a kid, it was bad. I was teased in school about it. My family refused to let me use it as an excuse. One day I decided to tell my grandfather that I stuttered and was being teased in school for it. He gave me a hug and said — “So? You going to let that stop you?” In his eyes, if you weren’t in Auschwitz… you’re OK. My parents would not let me use my stutter as an excuse to temper my curiosity (to not ask questions). They always expected my brother and I, from a very early age, to participate in dinner conversations with their friends. They were incredibly loving and determined for my brother and I to achieve whatever we wanted.”  https://lnkd.in/em3TwNg   #founders   #startup   #entrepreneur   #entrepreneurship   #innovation   #tech 
 
 
 …see more

content:
Love this: "My favorite story: A year ago I spent 20 minutes on a video conference call with a classroom full of faculty and staff at Babylon University in southern Iraq, answering questions about Python. Thanks to the efforts of the audacious woman who organized this event in a war-ridden country, students at Babylon University are now being taught introductory programming classes using Python. I still tear up when I think about the power of that experience. In my wildest dreams I never expected I’d touch lives so far away and so different from my own."  Guido van Rossum , Creator of the Python programming language.

I can’t tell you how many times I have to reminder founders about this. So many think the “competition” will kill their business. It’s not true - but their perceived fear of it happening will. Focus all - and I mean ALL - your efforts on what you’re doing and where you want to get to. The surest way to succeed is to keep going. So don’t be distracted. Share your dreams and work your a$$ off to achieve them.  I’m rooting for you.  {Quote via the great  Simon Sinek }

content:
How many of us will have the  #courage  and acumen to cannibalise 100% of our revenue-generating products and focus on emerging opportunities in the hope of taking our company to new heights? Intel Corporation  had a  #crisis  when the markets started moving towards cheaper and better memory chips. Andrew Grove, a legend to the engineers in the 80s, made massive successful  #pivots           - Taking Intel out of their dominant market, memory chips         - Entering the new emerging market for microprocessors         - Creating defensible competitive advantage that has lasted to this day While this year has been difficult for the society at large and for many of us in the start-up ecosystem, it has been especially difficult for founders. Others before us have faced  #crisis , albeit in different ways. Whether it was the financial crisis or the dot-com crash or an internal crisis specific to a company, there are so many examples of transformational companies and inspirational leaders that transcended a crisis. We can certainly learn from their journeys. These episodes of the  #KalaariPodcast  come from our continued commitment to empower and encourage entrepreneurs.  podcasts@kalaari.com https://lnkd.in/eAA6Wry

We are ready to launch  #KalaariFellowship  3.0, an initiative to develop young talent in Indian  #venturecapital  ecosystem. “The best way of learning about anything is by doing” is a philosophy I strongly believe in. Current world challenges require diverse thinking, peer groups with varied experiences,  #collaboration  for risk-taking, & patient determination amongst other traits. The Fellowship is an apprenticeship model where individuals work directly with senior members at  Kalaari Capital  to develop real-world skills & a  #leadership  voice.  We are looking for individuals who are impact-oriented, entrepreneurial, and self-driven. We highly value strong work ethics, integrity, passion, grit, and the ability to pursue excellence. Our best Fellows are problem solvers who bring a  #learning  mindset, great attitude, new ideas and fresh perspectives. Most importantly, they are willing to roll up their sleeves and get work done. If this excites you and think that you're a great fit, please do apply. More details below. (Glam has become the byword for working in a VC firm, successful VCs do work hard to keep up with their hardworking founders!) content:
According to National Geographic, “Extinction rates today are hundreds—perhaps thousands—of times higher. The last mass extinction, which did in the dinosaurs some 66 million years ago, followed an asteroid impact. Today the cause of extinction seems more diffuse. It’s logging and poaching and introduced pathogens and climate change and overfishing and ocean acidification. But trace all these back and you find yourself face-to-face with the same culprit. This time around, the asteroid is us." The photograph below shows the gap between what people in each country perceive as the percentage of protected land and water v/s what happens in reality. This made me think how we can be cocoon in our perceptions. How much do you think about climate change and personal choices? (Article link in comments)

content:
In the formative stages of a startup, hiring the right talent is among the most important things a founder will have to do. And it’ll be worth considering tapping into the skills and expertise of senior professionals while they are at it.  I am reminded of the book ‘Outliers’ by Malcolm Gladwell where he notes that 10,000 hours is the magic number for greatness. That you need to have practiced and to have apprenticed for at least 10,000 hours before you get good at a task. In fact, senior professionals and retirees come having incubated their skills and talent for much longer than that. And, therefore, they are worth more for their experience than what their age accredits them with. Whether you engage them full-time or part-time, as a consultant or as a part of the in-house team, it’s certainly a good idea for young founders enroll the expertise of someone who’s navigated the deep waters of a formal organization and can guide them in their journey to building one. Perhaps I am so much in favor of this because I am aging myself! Nevertheless, with average lifespan expected to improve in the years to come - 120 years as per some estimates - we have to start thinking about longer-term productivity measures and workforce inclusion.

content:
"What would you tell entrepreneurs that see your success and think you are too perfect to experience challenges?"🙄 Oh jeez. I had a fantastic call with best selling author of "Why Me First" and Mindset/Performance Coach,  Kajal Khurana  from Singapore. I had to contain my laughter on-air because I've been dealing with rejection a bit more than usual. Three opportunities fell apart over the past two weeks. A rejection from a local publication for the second time. Personal health issues. And more... But at this moment when I was supposed to mentor others, I was able to recenter and digest my own advice. ⬇ Lean into the rejection and understand that there is more out there for you. Your future holds greater things and losing these opportunities makes room for even BIGGER ones! Sometimes rejection is proof that you are going OUT there and doing MORE 👉 and that's a sign of effort on its own! Be proud of how far you've come, even if it isn't where you thought you should be. Agree? 👇 #Rejection 
 
 
 …see more

content:
Join Chantel Soumis and Jason Lebowitz as they continue their focus this week on Anxiety.  Anxiety is a normal and often healthy emotion. However, when a person regularly feels disproportionate levels of anxiety, it might become a medical disorder. Anxiety disorders form a category of mental health diagnoses that lead to excessive nervousness, fear, apprehension, and worry. Last week we began the conversation by talking about general anxiety.  Today's focus will be on Social Anxiety.  Social Anxiety is a chronic mental health condition in which social interactions cause irrational anxiety. For people with social anxiety disorder, everyday social interactions cause irrational anxiety, fear, self-consciousness, and embarrassment. Symptoms may include excess fear of situations in which one may be judged, worry about embarrassment or humiliation, or concern about offending someone. Come join in the discussion and leave your comments and questions.  The show streams live at 10 AM CST.

We were reminded of the legacy our family leaves behind and the gift of life we were handed. A gift of endless opportunity and the ability to do or be anything we set our hearts on... So... When you feel small, ❤ remember how special your story is. 🧡 embrace your struggles and adversity. 🤎 learn to love each twist and turn. You were built for more, and better yet, you DESERVE more... content:
The brilliant thing about growing as a professional is choosing the company you surround yourself with. Motivational speaker Jim Rohn famously said that we are the average of the five people we spend the most time with... So who is in your circle?  Who are you choosing to learn from and grow with? content:
Have you ever been stuck in a rut? Have you felt like you can't get out of it, no matter how hard you try? When you are diagnosed with an incurable disease like cancer, it's easy to grieve and get stuck in a mental rut. Even as the "bubbly and blessed" I have felt my fair share of darkness fighting illness! We get out. We fight through the pain. We rise up and make the best of a very dark situation! Because the clouds WILL part 🌩 and the sun will come back out 🌞 Weathering the storm isn't about the cards you have in your hand... but about how you play the cards you've been dealt. That's why I stepped up to this challenge... AND I HAVE LEARNED A LOT! ✅ I have been rejected over and over again... ✅ Folks I NEVER thought would make a contribution showed up with extreme generosity... ✅ While those I thought would give ignored my inquiry. And THAT'S OKAY. This is a big challenge, but I'm here to fight for the loved ones I've lost and know that as a parent, NO mother or father should EVER have to lose their baby to cancer. Let's cure it. This is my WHY for the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society  Please consider making a monetary or auction donation here:  https://lnkd.in/gdjKxAB #MWOY   #GiveBackChallenge   #Healthcare   #Gratitude

content:
Waiting on pins and needles, going crazy figuring out how to dress for the interview or how to wear your hair... Intimidated by body language and unexpected questions during the in-person interrogation, that makes your stomach flip... When I applied for a job as a Marketing Manager for an IT academy I was invited for an interview, One of the six people interviewing me started to pick on me for using the word "dazzled" in my cover letter. It was totally on brand,  But this engineer didn't dig that flavor or my bubbly nature, regardless of skill. Right then I knew it wasn't a fit. Needless to say, I went from having dreams of working for a small IT academy to writing for Thrive Global, working for millionaires across the globe on how to amplify their personal brand and thought influence. A lot has changed over the years. And I still use the word "dazzled" wherever possible 😉 Never dull your flavors to fit into someone else's recipe, especially when seeking a fit in your career. If you're looking for ways to build a culture that attracts and retains top talent, read my love story... #Culture   #Inclusion   #Success

content:
How many influential business leaders have you seen nix a little bit of fun as a waste of time and energy? This article from  The New York Times  is a refreshing reminder that "guilty-pleasures" are good for you. “A guilty pleasure is something that we enjoy, but we know we’re either not supposed to like, or that liking it says something negative about us. That negative thing often ends up being an association with categories of identity we disparage and marginalize in society.  Consider what separates sports and reality TV.  The idea of someone apologizing for watching the NBA finals sounds silly, but the implied apology when someone says, “Ugh, I know ‘The Bachelor is awful but I can’t stop watching it” is normalized." The Journal of Media Psychology conducted a study proving that playing a video game or watching a movie or television can restore some psychological resources and reduce stress. 🦄✨🦄 Yesterday I indulged in lemon bars, the purchase of a jacket covered in rainbow sequins, wearing my favorite pair of unicorn slippers while watching Dynasty on Netflix.  #NoGuilt 🦄✨🦄 BONUS READ Pleasure Activism: The Politics of Feeling Good #MentalHealth   #Leadership   #Happiness   #ChantelShares

content:
I've messed up. Because I haven't shown what it's really like owning a business. Here's "my" reality of being an entrepreneur. ✅ I've had two failed businesses. In 2018 my power was turned off multiple times because I wasn't making enough money. Early 2019, I slept on my office floor for 2 months while we got our company off the ground. ✅ My company has grown quickly. And it's been amazing. But 2019 was also a rough year. I skipped pay multiple times.  ✅ I had to walk miles to meetings because I totaled my car and didn't have enough money for Lyft. ✅ I rented out two of my apartment rooms at $500 a month each. It allowed me to live rent free a lot of 2018 while I focused on building my company. ✅ I've been called a 'n***er'. Laughed at during the first pitch event I ever went to. Friends turn into enemies. Fellow creators turn on me.  Don't become an entrepreneur because of what it looks like. This is the worst thing I've ever done in my life.  But it's also the most rewarding thing I have ever done. And I can't imagine doing anything else. I'm a business owner because of the freedom. Because it fuels my curiosity. Because it allows me to empower others. Share this video with someone that needs to see this! 🎥  #justQ  🖖🏾🖤  #entrepreneurship   #business

content:
I want to be honest with you. 👇🏽 I quit my full time job when I was 22 to start my first company. I had no plan. And I guess long term that worked out for me.  But where I wish I could go back and reframe my thinking is this: I thought it was wrong to build something on the side.  I thought I would lose respect if I took a part-time job (even though I was struggling to keep the lights on). I looked down on people that didn’t jump all in. Which was SO naive of me.  I thought building a business was easy. Because the people I followed kind of made it look easy. One of the things I struggle with most as a creator & entrepreneur is showing the reality. I don’t show: ✅ The boring stuff. ✅ Us getting ripped apart by our business coach every week 😅😭. ✅ How much work actually goes into this. ✅ The many mistakes we make.  ✅ And I could go on and on. Thank you  Cory Savage  for prompting this thought. And thank you i.c stars for asking me to do the commencement speech this year.  2020 I want to spend more time talking about (and showing) the stuff that many of us tend to avoid. What do you wish you knew when you first started? #justQ  🖖🏽🖤  #business   #entrepreneurship

content:
My TEDx was about standing out with a story. And there are few things that illustrate the power of story better than this.👇🏽 In the 60s a Harvard Psychologist, Robert Rosenthal, approached a school in California. Basically saying, “hey, I have this test I can give your students to help you identify which students are special.” The kids were then separated into two groups “average” and “special”. A year went by and the test was incredibly accurate. The “special” group blew the other group out of the water in everything from: test scores, curiosity, happiness, etc. Even the teachers were happier. The thing is, that test was 100% bullshit and the students were chosen at random.  So 1). A good story can help sell anything. And 2). Pay attention to the narratives that you’re telling yourself. Because stories have the power to create reality. #justQ  🖖🏽🖤  #entrepreneurship   #PublicSpeaking

content:
I’ve been called “too” competitive. I like to win. I like to learn. And culturally that’s been a bad thing. But I’m learning that if I’m going to “win” I need to lean more into the person that I am and make my strengths (and weaknesses) work for me. And for me it’s simple: am I outworking the old me? Am I better than the old me? Am I working towards the me that I want to be? At the end of the day there is no one on the planet with the same goals + plans as you. No point in competing with someone that’s playing a different game with different rules. Your only [long term] competition is you.  #justQ  🖖🏽🖤

content:
🛑 STOP quitting when you win — go until you can’t go anymore. 🛑  I was talking to one of my business coaches and he was explaining his wife’s mindset as a D1 high jumper.  - Every win she ever had ended in 3 subsequent failures. - She didn’t stop when she beat the rest of the competition. She stopped when she could no longer jump over the next height. I was a collegiate triple jumper so I totally resonate with that. And it’s shaped my mindset as an entrepreneur. Work every day to put yourself out of business. Push yourself. I’m not okay with being the best. I want to dominate, leave a legacy, and be the best version of me. What about you? #justQ  🖖🏽🖤

content:
Stories need conflict. So ask yourself, what's the conflict in your life? Over the past few years I've gotten so comfortable at opening up and sharing my past. But I'm not so great at sharing what's going on currently (because I'm always so focused on getting through it). But that's something I'm working on as I move forward.  Because conflict is a gateway to connection. It makes your story relatable. That doesn't mean that everything you share has to be about hardship. Or that you need a rags to riches story.  But trickling in the adversity that your facing (or have faced) is a great way to take your content & story to the next level. Just something to think about. #justQ  🖖🏽🖤

content:
Are you self-isolating? If you’re not, and you have the means to, you need to be! When I was 7 my parents and teachers didn't think I'd ever be able to read or do basic math, because of my debilitating dyslexia. I was lucky enough to work with an amazing educator who convinced me that my dyslexia was a superpower. My confidence grew, and I realized that the problem wasn't that I couldn't learn - it was that the standardized resources and tools being thrown at me were useless.  Once I was able to understand my dyslexia, I was able to master it and use it to my advantage. The same is true for ANY weakness. Get to know yourself. Get to know your faults. Then grab them by the horns, and use them to unleash your full potential.  Interviewer:  Bryan Elliott

content:
“Just checking in.” ⚠️ WARNING! ⚠️  Using “just” doesn’t make you sound less aggressive; it weakens your message, dilutes its impact, and signals that you and your request aren’t very important. Here’s how to drop it: First, become more mindful of your words🧠 Scan your  #emails , texts, and messages (and better yet, read them out loud). You might be shocked to learn how often that seemingly innocuous word pops up in  #communication .  Next, determine what you want🎯 Identify if you’re looking for a status update or trying to stay on someone’s radar—as well as the urgency— so you can craft an appropriate message. Finally, substitute new, action-oriented phrases🚀 Instead of “just checking in,” which screams “this isn’t important or timely” to your intended audience, try an equally polite but far more direct approach: “I’d love to hear how the (EVENT/PROJECT) is going/went. Could you give me a quick status update by end-of-day?” Or “Yikes! If your inbox is anything like mine, messages tend to get buried. I wanted to make sure things were still in progress. Let me know if you need any help.” By removing “just” from your  #business   #writing , you’ll add more power to your words and, more importantly, improve your chances of a speedy response. #leadership   #career   #IlluminateMe

content:
You’re only one decision away from a totally different life. Making a positive, life-changing decision requires three steps for success: 1. Awareness When we’re unhappy, it can often feel like there’s no way out, but you always have options. The first step in making a  #choice  is the  #awareness  that you have one. At this stage, it’s not about editing yourself on what’s possible; it’s about being mindful that change starts with you and your attitude. (Note: choosing not to make a change is also a choice; if you’re not changing it, you’re choosing it.) 2. Attention with Intention Once you’ve realized that change is an internal job, consider those things within your control and how they impact—for better or worse—what you want. Bring your  #attention  to your  #intention , and ask yourself what’s the one thing you can do right now to bring you closer to your  #goals . This need not be a grandiose, sweeping gesture; the biggest change starts with a small step in a new direction. 3. Action This last step may seem obvious, but far too often, we fail to act even when we know that making a change is in our best interest. Nothing changes if nothing changes. And action begets more action, giving us the much-needed momentum to keep going, no matter how slowly we start. #leadership   #career

content:
For so many of us, 2020 has been the year that won’t let up.😫 In these crazy times,  #uncertainty  continues to plague us in business can be crippling—or empowering—if we allow it to be. Here are some reminders to help you navigate a “what if” world: You can’t control what happens; you can only control how you respond.✅ No one asked for the year that 2020 has been and continues to be. Rather than ponder why this is happening and lament circumstances affecting your  #career , remember there is one thing you can control: your response. Be mindful of what you consume.🧠 “You are what you eat” doesn’t only pertain to food; the same can be said in terms of the information you consume and its effects on your mental and physical wellbeing. Be aware of the people and sources you allow into your orbit, limit your exposure to those that trigger you, and seek additional perspectives that provide a balance of encouragement and  #positivity . #Perspective  is everything.😄 Asking and answering “What if?” tends to bring out extreme anxiety. But remember, you always have two choices: the worst-case scenario where you’re paralyzed by fear or the best-case scenario where you allow yourself to imagine the possibilities and become empowered by the potential of good. #leadership   #awareness

content:
#Socialmedia  notifications aren’t just robbing your time and  #attention ; they’re also increasing your stress and anxiety.📲   Here’s why you should turn them off:   You’ll start your day less anxious🧘‍♀️ Instead of starting your day with a sense of dread, you’ll feel calm and peaceful, knowing that you’re not allowing external forces to dictate your mood.   It redirects your behavior to support conscious and intentional consumption🎯 When you reclaim your time as your own, you decide when you want to check and engage on social media.   You’ll have uninterrupted blocks of time to do deep work⏰ When you protect your time, you’ll find it easier to have blocks of time to immerse yourself in deep work.   You’ll be more productive and less busy✅ When you’re not scrolling through and checking notifications, you’ll have more time to do the things that matter most.   You’ll be more present for others❤️ When your notifications are off, your attention won’t be compromised, and you’ll be more present for those that matter most.   It reminds you of what’s truly urgent and important⚠️ With notifications off, you’ll realize that not everything requires an instant response, and not much is truly important and urgent.   #leadership   #career   #timemanagement   #productivity

content:
What and how you share your wisdom matters. Ask yourself if you’re committing these common  #thoughtleadership  sins: 1. You only share the wins Nothing is a bigger turnoff than someone who is continuously boasting. People respond to those who are genuine and admit when they’ve made a mistake. 2. You push your product or service Don’t make the mistake of using your platform for blatant self-promotion. Instead, provide value by serving, not selling.  3. You try to cover too much ground Stick to those few areas where you are expert. When you stay within your wheelhouse, your audience sees you as the go-to person. 4. You never get to the point Meandering signals that you’re unorganized and unsure. Keep to one brief, compelling message. 5. You share haphazardly or infrequently Regularly and consistently publish your wisdom, so your network looks forward to—and trusts—your insights and observations. 6. You post & ghost Merely posting isn’t enough; you want to start conversations and build relationships, so engage with those who engage with your posts. 7. You’re not telling a consistent career story People want to learn more about thought leaders. Create a cohesive, up-to-date and engaging presence that aligns with your content and supports your positioning. #personalbranding

content:
Here are 24 suggestions* to help you leap into a better career:   1. Let it go Let go of those people and things that support your history, not your destiny.   2. Embrace progress over perfection Reframe failure as an opportunity to learn and take action to combat your perfectionism.   3. Build in time to reflect Slow down, stop multitasking, let your mind wander, and pay attention to what bubbles up.   4. Focus on upping your “know, like, trust” factor Share your insights, listen more, and treat people with kindness and respect.   5. Just say ‘no’ Say no if it doesn’t excite you, speak to your values, further your mission in life, or help you achieve your goals.   6. Try saying ‘yes’ Say yes to new challenges and opportunities, invite collaboration, empower and affirm others, and create an environment where it’s safe to try, fail, learn and innovate.   7. Brush up on your soft skills Use soft skills to create environments that empower and ignite teams, delight customers, and fuel sustainable growth.   8. Master time-management Do, decide, delegate or delete tasks, eliminate distractions, embrace mono-tasking, work your own rhythms, and build in breaks to recharge.   *Part 1 of 3   #career   #leadership   #progress

content:
In a world where external demands and a cacophony of noise bombard us, taking the time to turn inward and think deeply may be the ultimate luxury—and the best way to figure out what’s next in your  #career .   Here’s how:   Be intentional with your time Treat reflection as essential to your  #careerdevelopment  by scheduling time to think.   Slow down & stop multitasking It’s impossible to think deeply and carefully about your future while you’re multitasking. Slow down to find clarity among your chaos.   Eliminate distractions Up your odds for reflection success by turning off notifications, silencing your phone, and closing down tabs.   Get up & out(side) Research says walks in nature enhance brain function, reduce stress, keep you energized, and improve creativity, which enables better reflection.   Allow your mind to wander During reflection, try not to limit yourself to predetermined topics, or impose any rigid standards.   Pay attention to what bubbles up Use your self-awareness to pay attention to how you’re feeling, your reactions, and any new ideas that arise during reflection.   Record & review your thoughts so you can take action Until you capture your thoughts and goals, you’ll never be able to devise a plan of action to achieve them.   #leadership

content:
Here are five reasons why saying yes is one of the best decisions you can make for your career: 1. It opens you up to new challenges and opportunities. If you wait until you feel ready to pursue an opportunity, chances are it’ll pass you by. Saying yes means that you’re open to moving past your comfort zone and embracing a new challenge.  2. It invites collaboration. There’s a reason improvisation is rooted in the phrase, “Yes, and...” Unlike no, which shuts down conversations and progress, saying yes opens up positive possibilities and invites others to build together, fostering collaboration, partnership, and further discussion. 3. It empowers and affirms others. As a leader, choosing to say yes acts as an affirmation to others and their ideas: I hear what you just said. You’re paying attention, and they matter. And giving the green light signals trust, which empowers others. 4. It creates an environment where it’s safe to try, fail, learn, and innovate. When you freely say yes, you create a risk-tolerant environment. You encourage innovation by trying new things and using the successes and failures as learning opportunities. 5. It makes life more fun. Saying yes can bring you new sources of joy and lead you on an incredible adventure. #leadership   #career   #growth

content:
I’ve learned a few things about  #content :   Just because you write something doesn’t make it valuable to someone else; it’s up to the reader to decide.   If you only use your content to sell, you’ll turn people off. Instead, strive to be of service.   If you go on and on, meandering your way through a very long post with little punctuation, run-on sentences, and no clear point, you’ll lose people.   If a reader takes the time to like, comment, and share your stuff, make sure to acknowledge their kindness.   And on that note, be sure to like, comment and share other people’s content that you think your network would find valuable. If it resonated with you, it probably will with others.   The best way to discover interesting and valuable content is to read — a lot.   Follow people whose writing you admire, whether in your industry or not, and seek many sources of information, even if it makes you uncomfortable. You never know what you’ll learn and from whom. Be open.   Content can inform, entertain, persuade, or inspire. Choose wisely.   Be yourself. Write the way you speak.   And be consistent — in your creation, your voice, your sharing, your engagement.   Because my biggest takeaway is this:  Content may be king, but content comes from people. And people connect with people.

content:
When you’re  #perceptive , you’re good at understanding and figuring things out. Perceptive people are insightful, intelligent, and able to see what others cannot. They envision the possibilities, embracing what could be, rather than being satisfied with the status quo of what is.   They use the  #softskills  of  #listening  to make them sensitive and responsive to their team’s needs;  #awareness  of others to fuel their ability to truly “see” people beyond the façade of their armored shells and then ask probing questions to understand better what matters most to them; and  #empathy  because they know the power of understanding their audience is paramount to business success.   These leaders realize that it’s not about them, and know that to  #communicate  and  #connect , they must put other people’s needs first.   Positive leaders tend to have a growth  #mindset  or one in which they believe they can—and will—improve, and see every opportunity as a chance to grow and learn.   They’re  #curious  and tolerant of new ideas and people and are less like to be thrown off course because of an unexpected setback. They empower others to make decisions. And their openness builds  #trust  naturally, which allows them to connect with others more easily.   #leadership   #positivity   #emotionalintelligence

content:
Gary Vaynerchuk  says it's one of the biggest things to which he attributes his success.  Simon Sinek  believes it's the most important instrument in a leader's toolbox. And  Oprah Winfrey  cites it as fundamental to leadership. The secret of their success is something that might surprise you: EMPATHY. This soft skill is often misunderstood and confused with its cousin, sympathy, which is feeling compassion for somebody.   But empathy is about putting yourself in someone else’s shoes and seeing things from their perspective.   How can YOU be more a more empathetic leader?   First, shift your mindset to put people first. See them as human beings rather than a means to the end of a transaction or task.   Next, ask thoughtful and probing questions that draw out implications and feelings.   Finally, use your awareness to give others your full attention and truly listen to what matters most to them.   When you do these things, you’ll better understand your customers, colleagues, and partners, and then be able to use those insights in ways to better serve and communicate with them.   And in this way, empathy can give you an edge as a leader—and as a human being.   #empathy   #leadership   #business   #success   #relationships   #communication   #growth   #softskills   #career   #HumansFirst   #growthmindset
